titlePage.titlePart: The Antiquary. A Comedy,Acted by Her MAIESTIES Servants AT The COCK_PIT. Written By SHACKERLY MERMION, Gent.

div1.head:
THE
ANTIQVARY.

sp.speaker: Lionell.
sp.p:
NOw Sir, let me bid you welcome to your country, and
the longing expectation of those friends that have almost
languished for the sight of you: I must flatter
him, and stroke him too, he will give no milk else.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I have calculated, by all the rules of Reason and
Art, that I shall be a great man; for, what singular quality concurs to
perfection and advancement, that is defective in me? take my feature
and proportion, have they not a kind of sweetness and harmony to
attract the eyes of the beholders? the confirmation of which, many
authentical judgments of Ladies have sealed and subscribed to.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: How do you Sir, are you not well?

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.p:
Next, my behaviour and discourse, according to the Court-garb,
ceremonious enough, more promising than substantial, able to
keep pace with the best hunting wit of them all: besides, Nature has
blessed me with boldness sufficient, and Fortune with means; what
then should hinder me? nothing but Destiny, villainous Destiny, that
chains virtue to darkness and obscurity: well, I will insinuate myself
into the Court, and presence of the Duke, and if he have not the
grace to distinguish of worth, his ignorance upon him.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: What, in a muse Sir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Cannot a Gentleman ruminate over his good parts, but you
must be troubling of him?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Wise men and fools are alike ambitious, this travelling motion
has been abroad in quest of strange fashions, where his spongy
brain has sucked the dregs of all the folly he could possibly meet with,
and is indeed more ass than he went forth; had I an interest in his
disgrace, I would rail at him, and perhaps beat him for it; but he is as
strange to me, as to himself, therefore let him continue in his beloved
simplicity.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Next, when he shall be instructed of my worth, and eminent
sufficiencies, he cannot dignify me with less employment, than
the dignity of an Ambassador; how bravely shall I behave myself
in that service, and what an ornament unto my country may I arrive
to be; and to my kindred? but I will play the Gentleman, and neglect
them, that is the first thing I will study.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Shall I be bold to interrupt you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Presently I will be at leisure to talk with you; it is no small point
in State policy, still to pretend only to be thought a man of action,
and rather than want a colour, be busied with a man's own self.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Who does this ass speak to? surely to himself; and it is impossible
he should ever be wise, that has always such a foolish
Auditory.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Then, with what emulous Courtship will they strive to entertain
me in foreign parts? and what a spectacle of admiration shall
I be made amongst these who have formerly known me? how dost
thou like my carriage?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Most exquisite, believe me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
But is it adorned with that even mixture of fluency and grace,
as are required both in a Statist and a Courtier?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
So far as the divine prospect of my understanding guides me,
it is without parallel, most excellent; but I am no professed Critique
in the Mystery.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Well, thou hast Linceus eyes for observation, or couldst never
have made such a cunning discovery of my practise: but will the Ladies
think you have that apprehension, to discern and approve of me?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Without question, they cannot be so dull or stonyhearted,
as not to be infinitely taken with your worth; why, in a while, you
shall have them so enamoured, that they will watch every opportunity
to purchase your acquaintance, then again revive it with often banqueting
and visits, nay and perhaps invite others, by their foolish example,
to do the like; and some, that despair of so great happiness,
will enquire out your haunts, and walk there two or three hours together,
to get but a sight of you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
O infinite, I am transported with the thought on it! it draws
near noon, and I appointed certain Gallants to meet me at the five
crown Ordinary; after, we are to wait upon the like beauties you talked
of, to the public Theatre: I feel of late, a strong and witty Genius
growing upon me, and I begin, I know not how, to be in love with
this foolish sin of Poetry.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Are you Sir? there is great hopes of you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
And the reason is, because they say, it is both the cause and
effect of a good wit, to which I can sufficiently pretend; for, Nature
has not played the stepdame with me.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: In good time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
And now you talk of time, what time of day is it by your
Watch?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: I have none, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
How, never a Watch? o monstrous! how do you consume
your hours, never a Watch? it is the greatest solecism of society that
ever I heard of: never a Watch?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: How deeply you conceive of it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
You have not a Gentleman, that is a true Gentleman, without
one; it is the main Appendix to a Plush-lining: besides, it helps
much to discourse; for, while others confer Notes together, we confer
our Watches, and spend good part of the day with talking of it.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Well Sir, because I will be no longer destitute of such a necessary
implement, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
A suit to me? let it alone till I am a great man, and then I
shall answer you with the greater promise, and less performance.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
I hope, Sir, you have that confidence, I will ask nothing
to your prejudice, but what shall some way recompense the deed.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What is it? be brief, I am in that point a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Usurp then on the proffered means,
Show yourself forward in an action
May speak you noble, and make me your friend.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A friend, what is that? I know no such thing.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: A faithful, not a ceremonious friend;
But one that will stick by you on occasions,
And vindicate your credit, were it sunk
Below all scorn, and interpose his life
Betwixt you and all dangers: such a friend,
That when he sees you carried by your passions
Headlong unto destruction, will so follow you,
That he will guide you from it; and with good counsel,
Redeem you from ill courses: and, not flattering
Your idle humour to a vain expense;
Cares not to see you perish, so he may
Sustain himself awhile, and raise a fortune,
Though mean, out of your ruins, and then laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why, be there any such friends as these?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: A word,
They walk like spirits not to be discerned,
Subtle and soft like air, an oily balm
Swimming over their words and action; but below it,
A flood of gall.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well, to the purpose, speak to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: If I stand linked unto you,
The Gordian knot was less dissoluble,
A rock less firm, or centre movable.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Speak your demand.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Do it, and do it freely then, lend me a hundred Ducats.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
How is that, lend you a hundred Ducats? not a --
I will never have a friend while I breathe first, no, I will stand upon my
guard; I give all the world leave to whet their wits against me, work
like Moles to undermine me, yet I will spurn all their deceits like a hillock:
I tell thee, I will not buy the small repentance of a friend or
whore, at the rate of a Livery.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: What is this? I dare not
Trust my own ears, silence choke up my anger;
A friend, and whore! are they two parallels,
Or to be named together? may he never
Have better friend, that knows no better how
To value them: well, I was ever jealous
Of his baseness, and now my fears are ended.
Pox on these travels, they do but corrupt
A good nature, and his was bad enough before.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
What pretty sparkle of humanity have we here? whose attendant
are you, my little knave?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I wait, Sir, on Master Lionell.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: It is well you are come, what says the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
I delivered your Letter to him, he is very sorry he can furnish
you no better; he has sent you twenty Crowns, he says, towards
the large debt he owes you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
A fine child, and delivers his tale with good method; where,
in the name of Ganimode, hadst thou this Epitome of a servitor?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
You would little think of what consequence and pregnancy this
imp is; you may hereafter have both cause to know, and love him --
What Gentlemen are these?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: One is my father.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I hear, your son, Sir, is returned from travel,
Grown up a fine and stately Gentleman,
Outstrips his compeers in each liberal Science.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I thank my Stars, he has employed his time
To the best use, can tender an account
Of all his journal: how he has arrived
Through strange discoveries, and compendious ways,
To a most perfect knowledge of himself;
Can give a model of each Princes Court,
And is become their fear; he has a mind
Equally poised, and virtue without sadness,
Hunts not for fame, through an ill path of life;
But is indeed, for all parts, so accomplished,
As I could wish or frame him.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: These are joys,
In their relation to you, so transcendent,
As than yourself, I know no man more happy:
May I not see your son?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: See where he stands,
Accompanied with young Lionell, the Nephew
To Viterano the great Antiquary.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I will be bold, by your favour, to endear
Myself in this acquaintance; noble Petrutio,
Darling of Venus, Minion of the Graces,
Let me adopt me heir unto your love:
That is yours by descent, and which your father,
A grave wise man, and a Magnifico,
Has not disdained.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am much bound to you for it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
See the abundant ignorance of this Age, he cites my father for
a President: alas, he is a good old man, and no more; there he stands,
he has not been abroad, not known the world; therefore, I hope, will
not be so foolishly peremptory, to compare with me for judgment,
that have travelled, seen fashions, and been a man of Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Seignior, your ear, pray let us counsel you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Counsel me! the like trespass again; sure the old man dotes:
who counselled me abroad, when I had none but mine own natural
wisdom for my protection? yet I dare say, I met with more perils,
more variety of allurements, more Circes, more Calipsos, and the
like, than ever were feigned upon Vlisses.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It showed great wisdom, that you could avoid them,
Give over and tempt your destiny no farther;
It is time now, to retire unto yourself:
Settle your mind upon some worthy beauty,
A wife will tame all wild affections;
I have a daughter, who, for youth and beauty,
Might be desired, were she ignobly born;
And for her dowry, that shall no way part you:
If you accept her, here before your friends,
I will betroth her to you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I thank you Sir, you would have me marry your daughter; is
it so?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: With your good liking, not otherwise.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
You nourish too great an ambition, what do you see in me,
to make such a motion? no, be wise and keep her; were I married to
her, I should not like her above a month at most.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How, not above a month?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I will tell you, Sir, I have made an experience that way on my
nature, when I have hired a creature for my pleasure, as it is the fashion
in many places, for the like time that I told you of; I have been so
tired with her before it was out, as no horse like me, I could not spur
my affection to go a jot further.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.p:
Well said boy, thou art even mine own son, when I was
young, it was just my humour.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: You give yourself a plausible commends.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I can make a shift to love, but having enjoyed, fruition kills
my appetite: no, I must have several objects of beauty, to keep my
thoughts always in action, or I am nobody.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.p: Still mine own flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Therefore I have chose Honour for my Mistress, upon whose
wings I will mount up to the heavens, where I will fix myself a constellation
for all this under-world of mortals to wonder at me.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.p:
Nay, he is a mad wag, I assure you, and knows how to put
a price upon his desert.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I can no longer stay to delate on these vanities, therefore Gallants
I leave you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What, is he gone? is your son gone?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.p: So it seems. Well Gallants, where shall I see you anon?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: You shall not part with us.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.p: You shall pardon me, I must wait upon my son.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Do you hear Signior? a pretty preferment.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: O Sir, the lustre of good clothes, or breeding
Bestowed upon a son, will make a rustic,
Or a mechanic father, to commit
Idolatry, and adore his own issue.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: They are so well matched, it were pity to part them.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well said little one, I think thou art wiser than both them
But this same scorn I do not so well relish;
A whoreson humorous fantastic Novice,
To contemn my daughter, he is not worthy
To bear up her train.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Or kiss under it.
Will you revenge this injury upon him?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Revenge! of all the passions of my blood,
It is the most sweet; I should grow fat to think on it,
Could you but promise.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Will you have patience?
Be ruled by me, and I will compass it
To your full wish; we will set a bait afore him,
That he shall seize as sharply, as Ioves Eagle
Did snatch up Ganimede.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Do but cast the plot,
I will prosecute it with as much disgrace
As hatred can suggest.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Do you see this Page then?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Aye, what of him?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: That face of his shall do it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What shall it do? methinks he has a pretty innocent countenance.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: O! but beware of a smooth look at all times:
Observe what I say, he is a Siren above,
But below a very Serpent; no female scorpion
Did ever carry such a sting, believe it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What should I do with him?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Take him to your house,
There keep him privately, till I make all perfect.
If ever Alchemist did more rejoice
In his projection, never credit me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You shall prevail, upon my faith, beyond
My understanding: and, my dapper squire,
If you be such a precious wag, I will cherish you;
Come, walk along with me: farewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Adieu.
Now I must travel, on a new exploit,
To an old Antiquary, he is my Uncle,
And I his heir; would I could raise a fortune
Out of his ruins: he is grown obsolete.
And it is time he were out of date; they say he sits
All day in contemplation of a statue:
With never a nose, and dotes on the decays,
With greater love, than the self-loved Narcissus
Did on his beauty: how shall I approach him?
Could I appear but like a Sibyl's son,
Or with a face, rugged, as father Nilus
Is pictured on the Hangings, there were hope
He might look upon me; how to win his love,
I know not: if I wist he were not precise,
I would lay to purchase some stale interludes,
And give him them, Books that have not attained
To the Platonic year, but wait their course,
And happy hour, to be revived again:
Then would I induce him to believe they were
Some of Terences hundred and fifty Comedies,
That were lost in the Adriatic sea,
When he returned from banishment: some such
Gullery as this, might be enforced upon him;
I will first talk with his man, and then consider.

div1.stage: Enter Lorenzo, Gasparo, Moccinigo, and Angelia.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How happed you did return again so soon, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I will tell you Sir, as I followed my son
From the Rialto, near unto the bridge,
We were encountered by a sort of Gallants,
Sons of clarissimos, and procurators
That knew him in his travels; whereupon
He did insinuate with his eyes, unto me,
I should depart and leave them.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Seems he was ashamed of your company.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Like will to like, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What grave and youthful Gentleman is that with you?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Not Signior Moccinigo?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You jest, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Aye, and there hangs a jest;
For, going to a Courtesan this morning,
In his own proper colour, his gray Beard,
He had the ill luck to be refused; upon which,
He went and died it; and came back again,
And was again, with the same scorn, rejected,
Telling him, that she had newly denied his father.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Was that her answer?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: It has so troubled him,
That he intends to marry; what think you, Sir,
Of his resolution?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Byrlady, it shows
Great haughtiness of courage; a man of his years,
That dares to venture on a wife.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: A man of my years? I feel
My limbs as able as the best of them,
And in all places else, except my lust,
As green as a Bay tree; and for the whiteness
Upon my head, although it now lie hid,
What does it signify, but like a tree that blossoms
Before the fruit come forth? and, I hope a tree
That blossoms, is neither dry nor withered.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But pray, what piece of beauty is that you mean
To make the object of your love?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Aye, there
You pose me; for I have a curious eye,
And am as choice in that point to be pleased
As the most youthful: here one's beauty takes me,
And there her parentage or good behaviour;
Another's wealth or wit: but I would have one,
Where all these graces meet, as in a centre.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: You are too ambitious, you will hardly find
Woman or beast that trots sound of all four,
There will be some defect.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Yet this I resolve on,
To have a Maid tender of age, and fair:
Old fish, and young flesh, thatis still my diet.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What think you of a Widow?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: By no means,
They are too politic a generation,
Proved so by Similes; many voyages
Make an experienced sea-man, many offices
A crafty knave; so, many marriages,
A subtle cunning Widow: no, I will have one
That I may mould, like wax, unto my humour.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This doting ass is worth, at least, a Million;
And though he cannot propagate his stock,
Will be sure to multiply. I will offer him my daughter;
By computation of age, he cannot
Live past ten years; by that time she will get strength
To break this rotten hedge of Matrimony,
And after have a fair green field to walk in,
And wanton where she please. Seignior, a word,
And by this guess my love; I have a daughter,
Of beauty fresh, of her demeanour gentle,
And of a sober wisdom: you know my estate;
If you can fancy her, seek no further.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Thank you Seignior, pray of what age
Is your daughter?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But sixteen at the most.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: But 16, is she no more? she is too young then.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: You wished for a young one, did you not?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Not that I would have her in years.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Well, mark what I say, when I come to her,
She will never be able to endure me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I will trust her.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I think your choice, Sir, cannot be amended,
She is so virtuous and so amiable.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Is she so fair and amiable? I will have her,
She may grow up to what she wants, and then
I shall enjoy such pleasure and delight,
Such infinite content in her embraces,
I may contend with Iove, for happiness.
Yet one thing troubles me.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: I shall live
So well on earth, I never shall think of any other joys.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I wish all joy to you; but, it is in the power
Of Fate, to work a miracle upon you:
You may obtain the grace, with other men,
To repent your bargain before you have well sealed it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Or she may prove his purgatory, and send him
To heaven the sooner.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Such like effects as these,
Are not unheard of in Nature.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: For all these scruples,
I am resolved; bring me, that I may see her:
Young hansom Ladies are like prizes at a Horse race, where
Every wellbreath'd Gentleman may put in for his share.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But are you resolved of this course, Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Yes, we will be mad once in our days, do an exploit for posterity
to talk of; will you join with me?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am at your graces disposing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
No grace, nor no respect, I beseech you, more than ordinary
friendship allow of; it is the only bar to hinder our designs.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Then Sir, what fashion you are pleased to appoint me, I will
be glad to put on.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It is well; for my part, I am determined to lay by all ensigns
of my royalty, for a while, and walk abroad under a mean coverture:
variety does well, and it is as great delight, sometimes, to shroud his
head under a course roof, as a canopy of gold.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But what is your intent in this?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I have a longing desire, to see the fashions of the vulgar; which,
should I affect in mine own person, I might divert them from their
humours; the face of greatness would affright them, as Cato did the
Floralia from the Theatre.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Indeed familiarity begets boldness.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It is true, indulgence and flattery, take away the benefit of
experience from Princes, which ennobles the fortunes of private men.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
But you are a Duke, Sir; and this descent from your honour,
will undervalue you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Not a whit: I am so toiled out with grand affairs, and dispatching
of Embassages, that I am ready to sink under the burthen.
Why may not an Atlas of State, such as myself, that bears up the
weight of a Commonwealth, now and then, for recreations sake, be
glad to ease his shoulders? has not Iupiter thrown away his rays and
his thunder, to walk among mortals? does not Apollo suffer himself
to be deprived of his quiver, that he may waken up his Muse, sometimes,
and sing to his harp.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Nay Sir, to come to a more familiar example; I have heard of a
Nobleman that has been drunk with a Tincker, and of a Magnifico
that has played at blow-point.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Very good then, take our degree is alike, and the act is as pardonable.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
In a humour, Sir, a man may do much: but how will you
prevent this discovery of you?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Very well, the alteration of our clothes, will abolish suspicion.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And how for our faces?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
They shall pass without any seal of disguise; who, never
thought on, will never be mistrusted.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Come what will, greatness can justify any action whatsoever,
and make it thought wisdom; but if we do walk undiscerned, it will be
the better: it tickles me, to think what a mass of delight we shall
possess, in being as it were the invisible spectators of their strange behaviours.
I heard, Sir, of an Antiquary, who, if he be as good at
wine, as at history, he is sure an excellent companion; and of one Petrutio,
who plays the Eagle in the clouds: and indeed, divers others
who verify the Proverb, So many men, so many humours.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
All these we will visit in order; but how we shall comply
with them, it is as occasion shall be offered, we will not now be so serious
to consider.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Well Sir, I must trust to your wit to manage it; lead on, I attend
you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: THis is the window, now, my noble Orpheus;
As thou affectest the name of Rarity,
Strike with the soul of Music, that the sound
May bear my Love on his bedewed wing,
To charm her ear; as when a sacrifice,
With his perfumed steam, flies up to heaven,
Into Ioves nostrils, and there throws a mist
On his enraged brow: o how my fancy
Labours with the success!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Cease your fools note there; I am not in tune,
To dance after your Fiddle: who are you?
What fancy groom, that dares so near intrude,
And with offensive noise, grate on my ears?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What more than earthly light breaks through that window,
Brighter than all the glittering train of Nymphs
That wait on Cynthia, when she takes her progress
In pursuit of the swift enchased Deer,
Over the Cretan or Athenian hills;
Or when, attended with those lesser stars,
She treads the azure circle of the heavens?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hey dey, this is excellent! what voice is that?
O, is it you? I cry you mercy, Sir;
I thought as much, these are your tricks still with me:
You have been sotting on it all night with wine,
And here you come to finish out your revels;
I shall be, one day, able to live private,
I shall, and not be made the Epilogue
Of all your drunken meetings: for shame away,
The rosie morning blushes at thy baseness.
Iulia, go throw the Music a reward,
And set them hence.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Divine Lucretia,
Do not receive with scorn, my proffered service:
O turn again, though from your arched brow,
Strung with disdain, and bent down to your eye,
You shoot me through with darts of cruelly.
Ah foolish man, to court the flame that burns him!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What would this fellow have?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Shine still, fair Mistress,
And though in silence, yet still look upon me;
Your eye discourses with more Rhetoric
Than all the gilded tongues of Orators.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Out of my pity, not my love, I will answer;
You come to woe me, and speak fair, it is well:
You think to win me too, you are deceived;
For when I hate a person, all his actions,
Though never so good, prove but his prejudice:
For flatteries are like sweet pills, though sweet,
Yet if they work not straight, invert to poison.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Why do you hate me, Lady, was there ever
Woman so cruel, to hate him that loved her?
O, do not so degenerate from Nature,
Which formed you of a temper soft as silk!
And to the sweet composure of your body,
Took not a drop of gall or corrupt humour,
But all your blood was clear and purified.
Then as your limbs are fair, so be your mind;
Cast not a scandal on her curious hand,
To say, she made that crooked, or uneven;
For virtue is the best, which is desired
From a sweet feature: Women crown their youth,
With the chaste ornaments of love and truth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This is a language you are studied in,
And you have spoke it to a thousand.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Never,
Never to any; for, my soul is cut so
To the proportion of what you are,
That all the other beauty in the world,
That is not found within your face, seems vile!
O that I were a veil upon that face,
To hide it from the world; methinks I could
Envy the very Sun, for gazing on you!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I wonder, that a fellow of no worth,
Should talk thus liberally; be so impudent,
After so many slightings and abuses
Extorted from me, beyond modesty,
To press upon me still: have not I told you
My mind in words, plain to be understood,
How much I hate you? can I not enjoy
The freedom of my chamber, but you must
Stand in my prospect? if you please, I will
Resign up all, and leave you possession.
What can I suffer, or expect more grievous,
From the enforcement of an enemy?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Do not insult upon my sufferings;
I had well hoped, I should receive some comfort
From the sweet influence of your words or looks;
But now must fly, and vanish like a cloud,
Chased with the wind, into the colder regions,
Where sad despair sits ever languishing;
There will I calculate my injuries,
Summed up with my deserts: then shall I find
How you are wanting to all good and pity,
And that you do but juggle with our sense;
That you appear gentle and smooth as water,
When no wind breathes upon it; but indeed,
Are far more hard than rocks of Adamant:
That you are more inconstant than your Mistress,
Fortune, that guides you; that your promises
Are all deceitful; and that wanton love,
Whom former Ages, flattering their vice,
And to procure more freedom for their sin,
Have termed a god, laughs at your perjuries.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will do this: why do so, ease your mind,
So I be free from you: there is no such torment,
As to be troubled with an insolent Lover
That will receive no answer; bonds and fetters,
Perpetual imprisonment, are not like it:
It is worse, than to be seized on with a Fever,
A continual surfeit. For Heavens sake, leave me,
And let me hear no more of you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is this the best rewards for all my hopes,
The dear expenses of youth and service,
Spent in the execution of your follies?
When not a day or hour, but witnessed with me,
With what great study, and affected care,
More than of fame or honour, I invented
New ways to fit your humour; what observance,
As if you were the arbitress of Courtship,
I sought to please you with: laid out for fashions,
And bought them for you, feasted you with banquets,
Read you asleep in the afternoon with Pamphlets,
Sent you elixirs and preservatives,
Paintings and powders, that would have restored
Old Niobe to youth; the beauty you pretend to,
Is all my gift: besides, I was so simple,
To wear your foolish colours, cry your wit up,
And judgment, when you had none, and swore to it;
Drank to your health, whole nights in Hippocrase,
Upon my knees, with more Religion,
Than ever I said my prayers, which heaven forgive me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are these such miracles? it was but your duty,
The tributary homage, all men owe
Unto our sex: should we enjoin you travel,
Or send you on an errand into France,
only to fetch a basket of Muskmelons,
It were a favour for you: put the case,
If that I were Hero, and you Leander;
If I should bid you swim the Hellespont,
Only to know my mind, methinks you might
Be proud of the employment: were you a Puritan,
Did I command you wait me to a Play,
Or to the Church, though you had no religion,
You might not question it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Pretty, very pretty!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And then, because I am familiar,
And deign, out of my nobleness and bounty,
To grace your weak endeavours with the title
Of courtesy, to wave my Fan at you,
Or let you kiss my hand; must we strait marry?
I may esteem you in the rank of servants,
To cast off when I please, never for a husband.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: If ever devil damned in a Woman's tongue,
It is in thine; I am glad yet you tell me this,
I might have else proceeded, and gone on
In the lewd way of loving you, and so
Have wandered farther from myself: but now
I will study to be wiser, and henceforth
Hate the whole gang of you, denounce a war,
Never to be reconciled, and rejoice in it,
And count myself blessed for it, and wish all men
May do the like to shun you: for my part,
If when my brains are troubled, with late drinking,
I shall have else the grace, sure, to forget you;
Then but my labouring fancy dream of you,
I will stare affrighted at the vision.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas how pitifully it takes it to heart;
It would be angry too, if it knew how.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come near me, none of you; if I hear
The sound of your approach, I will stop my ears,
Nay I will be angry, if I shall imagine
That any of you think of me: and for thy sake,
If I but see the picture of a woman,
I will hide my face, and break it: so farewell.

div1.stage:
Exit Lucretia.
Enter Lorenzo, Moccinigo, and Angelia.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What are you friend, and what is your business?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Whatever it be, now it is despatched.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This is rudeness.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: The fitter for the place and persons then.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How is that?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You are a nest of savages, the house
Is more inhospitable than the quicksands:
Your daughter sits on the enchanted bay,
A Siren like, to entice passengers,
Who viewing her, through a false perspective,
Neglect the better traffic of their life:
But yet, the more they labour to come near her,
The further she flies back, until at last,
When she has brought them to some rock or shelf,
She proudly looks down on the rack of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why, who has injured you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No matter who,
I will first talk with a Sphinx, ere converse with you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A word, expound your wrongs more to the full,
If you expect a remedy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I will rather
Seek out diseases, choose my death, and pine,
Than stay to be cured by you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: If you be so obstinate,
Take your course -- Why wife AEmilia,
Daughter Lucretia -- what is the matter here
With this same fellow, do you owe him money?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Owe him money Sir? does he look like one
That should lend money? he is a Gentleman,
And they seldom credit anybody.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well wife,
Where was your Matrons wisdom, that should keep
A vigilant care upon your house and daughter;
And not have suffered her to be surprised
With every loose aspect, and gracing eye,
That suck in hot and lustful motions?
You were best turn Bawd, and prostitute her beauty.

sp.speaker: AEmil.
sp.l: You were best turn an old ass,
And meddle with your Bonds and Brokage.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What was his business?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To tell you true, Sir, he is one of those,
Whom love and fortune have conspired to fool,
And make the subject of a woman's will;
His idle brain, being void of better reason,
Is filled with toys and humours, and for want
Of other exercise, he takes great pains
For the expressing of his folly: sometimes
With starts and sighs, hung head, and folded arms,
Sonnets and pitiful tunes; forgetting
All due respect unto himself, and friends,
With doxing on a Mistress; she again
As little pitying him, whose every frown
Strikes him as dead as fate, and makes him walk
The living monument of his own sorrow.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I apprehend; he came awooing to thee,

It is so; and thou didst scorn him girl,
it was well don
I will ease thee of that care, see I have brought
A husband to thy hand; look on him well,
A worthy man, and a Clarissimo.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A husband said, now Venus be propitious;
He looks more like the remedy of love,
A Julep to cool it; she that could take fire
at such a dull flame, as his eyes, I should
Believe her more than touch-wood.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: A ravishing feature,
If her condition answer but her feature;
I am fitted, her form answers my affection,
It arrides me exceedingly; I will speak to her:
Fair Mistress, what your father has proposed,
In the fair way of contract, I stand steady
To ratify, and let me not seem less
In your esteem, because I am so easy
In my consent; women love out of fancy,
Men from advice.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You do not mean in earnest,
Now Cupid deliver me.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: How, not in earnest?
As I am strong and mighty in desires, you wrong me to question it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good Sir, consider
The infinite distance that is between us
In age and manner.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: No distance at all;
My age is youthful, and your youth is aged.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But you are wise, and will you sell your freedom
Unto a female tyranny? in despair,
Ever to be quit, you run a strange adventure,
Without perceiving what a certain hazard,
A creature of my inclination
Is apt to draw you to.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: I cannot think it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is strange you will not believe me, unless I lay
My imperfection open; I have a nature
Ambitious beyond thought, quite given over
To entertainments and expense, no bravery
Thatis fashionable can escape me; and then
Unless you are of a most settled temper,
Quiet without passion, I shall make you
Horn mad with jealousy.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Come, come, I know
Thou art virtuous, and speakest this but to try me,
You will not be so adverse to your fortune,
And all obedience, to contradict
What your father has set down.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: These are my faults
I cannot help, if you will be so good
As to dispense with them.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: With all my heart; I forgive thee before thou offendest.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I am mighty stubborn, and self-willed.
And shall sometimes even long to abuse you;
And for my tongue, it is like a stone thrown down
Of an impetuous motion not to be stilled.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: All these cannot dismay me, for considering
How they are passions proper to your Sex,
In a degree they are virtues.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O my fate,
He will not be terrified: then, not to feed you
With further hopes, or pump for more excuses,
Take it in brief, though I am loath to speak,
But you compell me to it; I cannot love you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How do you speed, Sir, is she tractable,
Do you approve of her replies?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: I know not.
Guess you, she said she cannot love me; and it is
The least thing I should have mistrusted, I durst
Have sworn, she would never have made scruple of it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Not love you? come, she must, and shall: do you hear, housewife?
No more of this, as you affect my friendship.
What, shall I bring here a right worshipful Praetor
Unto my house, in hope you will be ruled,
And you prove recreant to my commands?
By my vexed soul, thou hast done a deed were able
In the mere questioning of what I bid,
Were not I a pious and indulgent father,
To thrust thee, as a stranger, from my blood.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Be not too rash, Sir, women are not won
With force, but fair entreaty: have I been versed
Thus long in the school of love? know all their arts,
Their practices, their ways and subtleties,
In all my encounters still returned a victor,
And have not left a stratagem at last
To work on her affection? let me suffer.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay, if you have that confidence, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Lady, a word in private with you.

sp.speaker: AEmil.
sp.l: Pray sweetheart,
What pretty youth is that?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Who, this same chicken?
He is the son of a great nobleman,
And my especial friend; his father is gone
Into the country to survey his lands,
And let new Leases, and left him in charge
With me, till his return.

sp.speaker: AEmil.
sp.l: Now, as I live,
It is a well favoured lad, and his years promise
He should have an ability to do,
And wit to conceal; when I take him single,
I will try his disposition.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: This for your sake,
I will undertake and execute.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: For my sake,
You shall not draw me to the fellowship
Of such a sin.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: I know it is pleasing to thee,
And therefore am resolved.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I may prevent you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What, are you resolved?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: We are even at a point, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What is more to be done, let us in and consider.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Well sirrah, but that I have brought you up, I would cashier
you for these reproofs.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Good Sir consider, it is no benefit to me, he is your Nephew
that I speak for, and it is charity to relieve him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
He is a young knave, and thatis crime enough; if we were
old in anything, though it were in iniquity, there were some reverence
to be had of him.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Why Sir, though he be a young knave, as you term him, yet he
is your kinsman, and in distress too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Why Sir, and you know again, that it is an old custom, which
thing I will no way transgress; for a rich man not to look upon any,
his kinsman in distress.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: It is an ill custom, Sir, and it were good it were repealed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I have something else to look after, have you disposed of those
relics as I bade you?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Well, thou dost not know the estimation of what thou hast
in keeping; the whole Indies, seeing they are but newly discovered,
are not to be valued with them: the very dust that cleaves to one
of those Monuments, is more worth than the ore of twenty Mines.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yet by your favour Sir, of what use can they be to you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
What use? did not the Seigniory build a state chamber for
Antiquities; and it is the best thing that ever they did, they are the Registers,
the Chronicles of the age they were made in, and speak the
truth of History, better than a hundred of your printed Commentaries.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yet few are of your belief.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
There is a box of coins within, most of them brass, yet each
of them a Jewel, miraculously preserved in spite of time or envy;
and are of that rarety and excellence, that Saints might go a pilgrimage
to them, and not be ashamed.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Yet I say still, what good can they do to you, more than to
look on?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
What good, thou brute? if thou wert not worth a penny,
the very showing of them were able to maintain thee; let me see now,
if you were put to it, how you could advance your voice in their
commendation, begin.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
All you Gentlemen, that are affected with rarities, such, the
world cannot produce the like, snatched from the jaws of time, and
wonderfully collected by a studious Antiquary; come near, and
admire.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Thou sayst right, the limbs of Hippolitus were never so
dispersed.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
First, those twelve pictures that you see there, are the
portraitures
of the Sibyls, drawn 500 years since by Titianus of Padua,
an excellent Painter and Statuary.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Then here is Venus all naked, and Cupid by her, on a Dolphin;
both these were drawn by Apelles of Greece.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Then here is Hercules and Anteus, and that Pallas at length
in Alabaster, with her helmet and feathers; and that Iupiter, with
an Eagle at his back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Then there is the great silver box that Nero kept his beard in.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Good again.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
And after, decking it with precious stones, did consecrate it
to the Capitoll.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thatis right.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
And there hangs the Net that held Mars and his Mistress, while
the whole bench of bawdy Deities, stood spectators of their sport.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Admirable good.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Then here is Marius to the middle, and there Cleopatra, with a
veil over her face; and next to her, Marcus Antonius the Triumvir
then he with half a nose is Corvinus, and he with never one is Galbo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Very sufficient.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Then here is Vitellius, and there Titus and Vespasian, these three
were made by Iacobus Sansovinus the Florentine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is enough.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Last of all, this is the Urn that did contain the ashes of the
Emperors.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And each of these worth a Kings ransom --

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Save you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I come, Sir, a suitor to you; I hear, you are possessed of many
various and excellent antiquities, and though I am a stranger, I
would entreat your gentleness a favour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
only that you would vouchsafe me, to be a spectator of
their curiosity and worth; which courtesy shall engage me yours forever

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
For their worth, I will not promise, it is as you please to esteem
of them.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
No doubt Sir, we shall scribe what dignity belongs to them,
and to you their preserver.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
You speak nobly; and thus much let me tell you to your edifying,
the foolish doting of these present novelties, is the cause why
so many rare inventions have already perished; and which is pity,
Antiquity has not left so much as a footstep behind her, more than
of her vices.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It is the more pity, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Then, what raises such vanities amongst us, and sets fantastical
fancies awork; what is the reason that so many fresh tricks, and
new inventions of fashions, and diseases come daily over sea, and land
upon a man, that never durst adventure to taste salt water, but only
the neglect of those useful instructions which Antiquity has set down.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You speak oracles, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Look farther, and tell me what you find better, or more honourable
than age; is not wisdom entailed upon it? take the pre-eminence
of it in everything, in an old friend, in old wine, in an old
pedigree.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: All this is certain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I confess to you Gentlemen, I must reverence and prefer the
precedent times before these, which consumed their wits in experiments;
and it was a virtuous emulation amongst them, that nothing
which should profit posterity, should perish.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It argued a good fatherly providence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
It did so; there was Lisippus, that spent his whole life in the
lineaments of one picture, which I will show you anon; then was there
Eudoxus the Philosopher, who grew old in the top of a mountain, to
contemplate Astronomy, whose Manuscript I have also by me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Have you so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I have that and many more; yet see the preposterous desires
of men in these days, that account better of a mass of gold, than
whatever Apelles or Phidias have invented.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: That is their ignorance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Well Gentlemen, because I perceive you are ingenious, I
would entreat you to walk in, where I will demonstrate all, and proceed
in my admonition.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
It is well Sir, I am glad you are so soon got free from your
bondage.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Yes, I thank my stars, I am now my own man again, I have
slept out my drunken fit of Love, and am recovered; you that are
my friends, rejoice at my liberty.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Why, was it so painful to you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
More tedious than a siege; I wonder what black leaf in the
book of Fate, has decreed that misery upon man, to be in love; it
transforms him to a worse monster than ever Calipso's cup did: a
country Gentleman among Courtiers, or their wives among the Ladies,
a Clown among Citizens, nay an Ass among Apes, is not half
so ridiculous as that makes us; o that I could but come by it, how
I would tear it, that never a witched passion should arise in any
human breast again.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
You are too violent in your hate; you should never so fall out
with a friend, as to admit no hope of reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
I will first be at peace with a Serpent, mark me, if thou hast care
of thy time, thy health, thy fame, or thy wits, avoid it.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
I must confess, I have been a little vain that way, yet never so
transported, but when I saw a handsomer in place, I could leave, the
former, and cleave to the latter; I was ever constant to beauty.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Hold thee there still, and if there be a necessity at any time,
that thou must be mad, let it be a short fury, and away; let not this
paltry love hang too long upon the file, be not deluded with delays,
for if these she-creatures have once the predominance, there shall be no
way to torture thee, but they will find it out, and inflict it without mercy;
they will work on thy disposition, and if thou hast any good nature,
they will be sure to abuse thee extremely.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Speak you this in earnest?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
I know not what you call earnest, but before I will endure that
life again, I will bind myself to a Carrier, look out any employment
whatever, spend my hours in seeing motions and Puppet plays, look at
Bowling-alleys, mould tales, and vent them at Ordinaries, carry begging
Epistles, walk upon projects, transcribe Fiddlers ditties.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: O monstrous!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
But since I have tasted the sweetness of my freedom, thou
dost not know what quickness and agility is infused into me, I feel
not that weight was wont to clog me, wherever I went; I am all
fire and spirit, as if I had been stripped of my mortality: I hear not my
thoughts whisper to me as they were wont; such a man is your rival,
there is an affront, call him to an account, redeem your Mistress favour,
present her with such a gift, wait her at such a place; none of these
vanities.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: You are happy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Come gentles, follow me, I will bring you to them, look you
where they are.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Signior Lionell, I have traced much ground, to enquire for you.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: I rest engaged to you for your last nights love, Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
And I for your good company: did you ever see such a blind
ruinous tipling house, as we made shift to find out?

sp.speaker: Leo.
Lio.
sp.p: And what a deluge of Rheum?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
If the house be so old as you speak of, it were good you brought
my Master into it, and then throw it on top of him, he would never desire
to be better buried.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Well said, Petro.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Sir, if it be no trouble to you, I would entreat you know my
worthy friend here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You shall make me happy in any worthy acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Pet.
Lio.
sp.p: And what was the issue?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
He is hide-bound, he will part with nothing; there is an old rivelled
purse hangs at his side, has not been loosed these twenty years,
and I think, will so continue.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Why, will his charity stretch to nothing, Petro?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yes, he has sent you something.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
Lio.
sp.p: Thank him heartily.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
And it is the first; he says, that ever was made of them, and in
his esteem, is worth three double Ducats newly stamped.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
His folly may put what price he please upon it, but to me it is no
more than the value, Petro.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
He says moreover, that it may stand you in some use and pleasure
hereafter, when you grow ancient; for it is worn so thin with often
handling, it may serve you for a Spectacle.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It were a good deed to conspire against him, he has a humour
easy to be wrought on, if you will undertake him, we will assist you
in the performance.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: With all my heart, Gentlemen, and I thank you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Let us defer it no longer then, but instantly about it.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: A match, lead on, good wit and fortune guide us.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: BOy, how sits my Rapier?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Close Sir, like a friend that meant to stick to you.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
He that will purchase honour, and the name of Bravo, must
by consequence be a brave fellow, his titles requires it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But pray Sir, were you never put to the worst in your days?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Who, I worsted? no Boy; I do manage my Rapier with as
much steadiness and facility, as a Vincor does his Antler.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sure you must needs be very strong then.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Not so neither, it is courage in me, I do it by a slight, an activity,
and by that I can control any man's point whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
I tell thee, Boy, I do as much surpass Hercules at my Rapier,
as he did me in Club-fighting: have you drawn a Register of
those men, that have been forced by this weak instrument, to lay down
their lives, I think it has cut more lives than Atropos.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But pray Sir, were they all your own exploits?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Indeed Boy, thou mayst question it; for, if they were to perform
again, they would hardly be done: what will this age come to?
where be those stirring humours, that were wont to trouble the world?
peace, I think, will overspread them all like a gangrene, and men will
never dye with a Lethargy: there is no malice extant, no jealousies, no
employment to set wickedness awork; it is never a dead time with me,
but when there is nobody to kill.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Thatis a miserable extremity, indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Leave me, Boy, to my meditations --

Well, go thy ways, old Nick Machivell, there will never be the
peer of thee, for wholesome policy and good counsel, thou tookest
pains to chalk men out the dark paths and hidden plots of murther
and deceit, and no man has the grace to follow thee; the age is unthankful,
thy principles are quite forsaken, and worn out of memory.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
There is a fellow walks melancholy, and thatis commonly a
passion apt to entertain any mischief, discontent and honestly seldom
harbour together; how scurvily he looks; like one of the devils factors;
I will tempt him: by your leave Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: No hurt, good Sir, be not so furious, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
I am bold to disturb you, and would fain communicate a business,
if you had the patience to hear me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Speak, what is it?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
You seem a man, upon whom Fortune perhaps has not cast
so favourable an aspect, as you deserve.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Can you win her to look better?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Though not her, yet perhaps a servant of hers, that shall be
as gracious to you, and as profitable.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: What is she?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
It may be you want money, there is a way to purchase it, if
you have the heart.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
The heart! hast thou the heart to speak, nay to conceive what
I dare not undertake?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
A fit instrument for my purpose, how luckily has Fortune
brought me to him? do you hear Sir, it is but the slight killing of a
man, or so, no more.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: Is that nothing?

sp.speaker: Bra.
Moc.
sp.p: Nay, he is a Gentleman, and a Citizen of Venice.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Let him be what he will, if we can agree; it has been a foolish
ambition heretofore, to save them, and men were rewarded for it with
Garlands; but I had rather destroy one or two of them, they multiply
too fast.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Do you know one Signior Aurelio then? he is the man, he
wooed my Mistress, and sought to win her from me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: A warrantable cause; show me the man, and it is enough.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: And what must I give you?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: At a word, 30 Livres, I will not bate you a Betso.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: I will give you twenty.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
You bid like a chapman: well, it is a hard time; in hope of your
custom hereafter, I will take your money.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
There it is; now for the means, how can you compass it?
were you not best poison him, think you?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
With a Bullet or Stiletto, poison him? I scorn to do things so
poorly; no, I will use valour in my villainy, or I will do nothing.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
You speak honourably, and now I think on it, what if you beat
him well-favouredly, and spared his life?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Beat him? stay there, I will kill him for this sum, but I will not
beat him for thrice the value; so he might do as much for me: no, I will
leave him impotent for all thought of revenge.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Well Sir, use your pleasure -- Look you, here is the Gentle-woman,
for whose sake it is done -- Lady, you are come most opportunely,
to be a witness of my love and zeal to you; he is the man
that will do the feat.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What feat?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
That you and I consulted of, kill the rascal Aurelio, take him
out of the way; what should he live any longer for? I will have no man
breathe, that you disgust.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then ought you to go and hang yourself.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Who, I hang myself, for what? my good service, and respect
of your quiet? if he have any mind to haunt your chamber hereafter,
he shall do it as a ghost, without any substantial shape, I assure
you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I think the fool be in earnest, I must use policy, and not play
away a man's life so, nay prithee sweet-heart be not angry, it was but
to try thee: this kiss, and my love.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: Why, here is some amends yet, now it is as it should be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am as deep, and eager in this purpose,
As you are, therefore grant me leave, a little,
To talk with him; I have some private counsel
To give him, for the better execution.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: May I not hear?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No, as you love me, go.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Her humour must be law; we that are suitors,
Must deal with women, as with towns besieged,
Offer them fair conditions, till you get them,
And then we will tyrannize: yet there is a doubt,
Is not resolved on.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good Sir, be gone.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: I vanish: were I best trust this fellow with my Mistress?
Temptations may arise; it is all one, I am
A right Italian, and the world shall see,
That my revenge is above jealousy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Now Lady, your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I would not allow myself any conference with you, did my
reason persuade me, that you were as bad as you seem to be: pray
what are you?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
I am, sweet creature, a kind of lawless Justicer, or usurping
Martialist of authority, that will kill any man with my safety.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And you purpose the death of this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I will do anything for hire.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Have you no conscience?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Conscience! I know what it is: why should any man live, and
I want money?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Have you no regard then of innocence?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: It is crime enough, he has a life.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How long have you been versed in this trade?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: It is my vocation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Leave it, it is damnable;
And thou, the worst and basest of all villains,
It had been better for the womb that bare thee,
If it had travelled with pestilence:
What seed of Tigers could beget thee to
Such bold and rash attempts? for a small lucre,
Which will be strait as ill spent as it was got,
To destroy that, whose essence is divine;
Souls in themselves more pure than are the heavens,
Or thy ill boding stars; more worth than all
The treasure locked up in the heart of earth,
And yet do this unmoved or unprovoked.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I have no other means, nor way of living.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It were better perish, than be so supported,
There are a thousand courses to subsist by.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Aye; but a free and daring spirit scorns
To stoop to servile ways, but will choose rather
To purchase his revenue from his sword.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I see you are grown obdurate in your crimes,
Founded to vice, lost to all piety;
Without the apprehension of what wrong
You do your Country, in depriving her
Of those she now enjoys, as useful members,
But killing their posterity, who perhaps
Might with their art or industry advance her.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What courteous itch, I wonder, has possessed
Your virtuous Ladyship to give me advice?
Best keep your wits, until you get a husband,
Who may perhaps require your learned counsel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is true, such as do act thy villainies,
Hate to be told, or think of them; but hear me,
Hast thou no sense? nor no remorse of soul?
No thought of any Deity, who though
It spare thee for a while, will send at last
A quick return of vengeance on thy head,
And dart thee down like Phaeton.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sweet virgin,
Faces about to some other discourse,
I cannot relish this.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So I believe, but yet,
Compose your thoughts for speedy penitence,
Your life for an amendment, or I vow,
To lay your actions open to the Senate.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Did not your sweetheart tempt me to this deed,
And will you now betray me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: He my sweetheart,
I hate you both alike; that very word
Is enough to divorce thee from my pity,
Past hope of reconcilement; for what mercy
Is to be had of two such prodigies;
Will you recant yet? speak, will you be honest.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I think you will force me to become your patient

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is the way to heal thee of a sore
Whose cure is supernatural; what art,
What mirror is sufficient to demonstrate
The foulness of the guilt? whose leprous mind
Is but one stain, seas cannot cleanse? why, murder
It is of all vices the most contrary
To every virtue, and humanity;
For they intend the pleasure and delight,
But this the dissolution of nature.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: She does begin to move me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Think of thy sin,
It is the end apparent unto hell,
And has so many, and so ugly shapes,
His father Pluto, and the furies hate

To look on their own birth, yet thou
darest act
What they fear to suggest, and sell thy soul
To quick perdition.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: This has waked me more,
Into a quicker insight of my evils,
That have impaled me round with horrid shapes;
More various, than the several forms of dreams
That wait on Morpheus in his sleepy den.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then it is a fearful sin, and always labours
With the new birth of damned inventions
And horrid practises; for it is so fearful,
It dares not walk alone, and where it bodes,
There is no rest, nor no security,
But a perpetual tempest of despair.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: All this I feel by sad experience,
Where have I been, where have I lived a stranger,
Exiled from all good thoughts? never till now
Did any beam of grace, or good, shine on me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Besides, it is so abhorred of all thatis good,
That when this monster lifts his cursed head
Above the earth, and wraps it in the clouds,
The Sun flies back, as loath to stain his rays
With such a foul pollution; and night,
In emulation of so black a deed,
Puts on her darkest robe to cover it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O do not grate too much upon my sufferings,
You have won upon my conscience, and I feel
A sting within me, tells my troubled soul,
That I have trod too long those bloody paths
That lead unto destruction.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then be sorry,
And with repentance purge away thy sin.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Will all my days and hours, consumed in prayers,
My eyes dissolved to tears, wash off such crimes?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If they be serious, and continued.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You are a virgin, and your vows are chaste,
Do you assist me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So you will do the like
For me in what I shall propose.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will,
And joy to be employed, there is no thought
Which can proceed from you, but which is virtuous:
And it is a comfort, and a kind of goodness,
To mix with you in any action.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay more, in recompense of your fair proffer,
Because you say, you are destitute of means,
I will see that want supplied.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Divinest Lady,
Command my service.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Walk then in with me,
And then I will acquaint you with the project.

div1.stage: Enter Duke, Lionell, and Leonardo, Petrutio following.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I see him coming, let us fall into admiration of his good parts,
that he may overhear his own praise.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: I have, methinks, a longing desire to meet with Signior Petrutio.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I hear myself named amongst them, it is no point of civility, to
listen what opinion the world holds of me, I shall conceive it by their
discourse, a man behind his back, shall be sure to have nothing but
truth spoke of him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Pray Sir, when saw you that thrice noble and accomplished
Gentleman, Petrutio.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Thrice noble, and accomplished! there is a new style thrust
upon me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It pleased the indulgency of my fate, to bless me with his
company this morning, where he himself was no less favourable to
grace me with the perusal of a Madrigal, or an essay of Beauty, which
he had then newly composed.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Well Gallants, either my understanding misinforms me, or he
is one of the most rare and noble qualified piece of Gentility, that ever
did enrich our Climate.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Believe it Sir, it were a kind of profanation, to make doubt
of the contrary.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
How happy am I in such acquaintance? a man shall have his
due, when your meaner society has neither judgment to discern worth,
nor credit to commend it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It was my happiness, the other day, to be in the presence with
certain Ladies, where I heard him the most extolled and approved; one
of them was not ashamed to pronounce it openly, that she would never
desire more of heaven, than to enjoy such a man for her servant.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: It shall be my next employment, to enquire out for that Lady.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p:
It is a miracle to me, how, in so small a competencie of time, he
should arrive to such an absolute plentitude of perfection.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p:
No wonder at all, a man that has travelled, and been careful
of his time.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
But by your favour, Sir, it is not every man's happiness, to make
so good use of it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I will resolve you something, there is as great a mystery to the
acquisition of knowledge, as of wealth; have you not a Citizen will
grow rich in a moment, and why not be ingenious, besides who
knows but he might have digged for it, and so found out some concealed
treasure of understanding.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now, as I am truly noble, it is a wrongful imputation upon me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Well, if he had but bounty annexed to his other sufficiencies,
he were unparalleled.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Nay, there is no man in the earth more liberal, take it upon
my word, he has not that thing in the world so deer or precious in his
esteem, which he will not most willingly part with, upon the least summons
of his friend.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Now must I give away some two or three hundred pounds
worth of toys, to maintain this assertion.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p:
You spoke of verses even now, if you have the copy, pray
vouchsafe us a sight of them.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I cannot suddenly resolve you; yes, here they are.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: What is this?
sp.l: A Madrigal of Beauty.

l.emph: If I should praise her virtue and her beauty,
And tell how every grace doth her become:
But I should fail in the expression.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Aye marry Sir, this sounds something like excellent.

l.emph: Although I cannot write what I conceive;
That what I fail to speak, you would admire.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Why this had some taste in it, how should he arrive to this
admirable invention?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Are you so preposterous in your opinion, to think that Wit
and Elegancy, in writing, are only confined to Stagers and Book-worms?
it were a Solecism, to imagine, that a young bravery, who
lives in the perpetual sphere of humanity, where every waiting woman
speaks perfect Arcadia, and the Ladies lips distill with the very
quintessence of Conceit, should be so barren of apprehension, as not
to participate of their virtues.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Now I consider, they are great helps to a man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
But when he has travelled and delibated, the French and the
Spanish can lie abed, and expound Astrea, and digest him into complements;
and when he is up, accost his Mistress with what he had read
in the morning, that if such a one should rack up his imagination, and
give wings to his muse, it is credible, he should more catch your delicate
Court ear, than all your head-scratchers, thumb-biters, lamp-wasters
of them all.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Well, I say the iniquity of Fortune appears in nothing more,
than not advancing that man to some extraordinary honours.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: But I never thought he had any genius that way.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
What, because he has been backward to produce his good
qualities? believe it, Poetry will out, it can no more be hid, than
fire or love.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I will break them off, they have even spoken enough in my behalf
for nothing, a conscience; save you Cavalieros.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
My much honoured Petrutio, you are welcome; we were
now entered into a discourse of your worth, whether do your occasions
enforce you so fast?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Gentlemen, to tell you true, I am going upon some raptures.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Upon raptures, say you?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Yes, my employment is tripartite, I have here an Anagram to a
Lady, I made of her name this morning; with a Posy to another, that
must be inferred into a ring: and here is a paper carries a secret word
too, that must be given, and worn by a Knight and a Tilter; and all my
own imaginations, as I hope to be blessed.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Is it possible? how, have you lately drunk of the horse-pond,
or slept on the forked Parnassus, that you start out so sudden a Poet?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Tut, I leave your Elisions, and your pale Pyreus, to such as
will look after them; for my own part, I follow the instigation of my
brain, and scorn other helps.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Do you so?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I will justify it, the multiplicity of Learning does but distract a
man; I am all for your Modern humours, and when I list to express
a passion, it flows from me with that spring of amorous conceits, that
a true Lover may hang his head over, and read in it, the very Physiognomy
of his affection.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why this is a rare mirror.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It is so indeed, and beyond all the art of Optics.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
And when my head labours with the pangs of delivery, by
chance, up comes a Countesses waiting-woman, at whose sight, as at
the remembrance of a Mistress, my pen falls out of my hand; and then
do I read to her half a dozen lines, whereat we both sit together, and
melt into tears.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pitiful hearted, carted creatures.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I am now about a device, that this Gentleman has promised
shall be presented before his Highness.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes, upon my word Sir, and yourself with it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Shall the Duke take notice of me too? o Heavens, how you
transport me with the thought on it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I will bring you to him, believe me, and you know not what
grace he may do you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
It is a happiness beyond mortals: I cannot tell, it may be my
good fortune to advance you all.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: We shall be glad to have dependence on you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Gentles I would entreat you a courtesy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What is that Signior?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
That you would all be pleased to grace my lodging tomorrow,
at a Banquet, there will be Ladies and Gallants; and among the
rest, I will send to invite your Uncle the Antiquary, and we will be very
merry, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well Sir, your bounty commands us not to fail you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Bounty! there is a Memorandum for me; in the mean time,
pray accept these few favours at my hands, as assurances that you will
not fail me; till when, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Farewell Sir, go thy ways, thou hast even as dull a piece of
scalp, as ever covered the brain of any traveller.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
For loves sake, Lionell, let us haste to thy Uncle, before the coxcomb
prevent us.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Why Sir, I stay for you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Has Petro prepared him for your entrance? and is your disguise
fit?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: I have all in a readiness.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
On then, and when you are warm in your discourse, we will
come with our device to affright him: it will be an excellent scene
of affliction.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Be sure you mark your Cue, Sir, and do not fail to approach.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Trust to my care, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman without speak with me, say you?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and will by no means be put back.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
I am no Lawyer, nor no Secretary: what business can she
have here, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: She is very importunate to enter.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
I was once in the humour, never to admit any of them to come
near me again, but since she is so eager, let her approach: I will try my
strength, what proof it is against her enchantments; if ever Vlisses were
more provident, or better armed to sail by the Sirens, I will perish if she
have the art to impose upon me, let her beg my wit for an Anatomy:
and dissect it --

Now Lady Humour, what new motion in the blood has turned the
tide of your fancy, to come hither?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: These words are but unkind salutes to a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
They are too good for you, with what face dare you approach
hither, knowing how infinitely you have abused me? you want matter
to exercise your wits on, the world is too wise for you, and ere you ensnare
me again, you have good luck.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Pray Sir, do not reiterate those things which might better be
forgotten; I confess I have done ill, because I am a woman, and young,
and it will be nobleness in you, not to remember it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
I will sooner plough up shore and sow it, and live in expectation of
a crop, before I will think the least good from any of your sex, while I
breathe again.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I hope, Sir, that time and experience will rectify your judgment,
to a better opinion of us.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
I will trust my ship to a storm, my substance to a broken Citizen,
ere I will credit any of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Good Sir, be entreated, I come a penitent Lover, with a vowed
Recantation to all former practices, and malicious endeavours, that I
have wrought against you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
How can I think better of you, when I consider your nature,
your pride, your treachery, your covetousness, your lust; and how
you commit perjury, easier than speak.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Sure it is no desert in us, but your own misguided thoughts, that
move in you this passion.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Indeed, time was, I thought you pretty foolish things to play
withal; and was so blinded, as to imagine, that your hearts were golden
threads, that your eyes darted forth beams, that laughter sate smiling
on your lips, and the Coral itself looked pale to them; that you
moved like a goddess, and diffused your pleasures wide as the air:
then could I prevent the rising Sun to wait on you, observed every nod
you cast forth, had the patience to hear your discourse, and admired
you, when you talked of your visits, of the Court, of Counsels, of Nobility,
and of your Ancestors.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And were not these pleasing to you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Nothing but a heap of tortures: but since I have learned the
Delphic Oracle, to know myself, and ponder what a deal of mischief
you work, I am content to live private and solitary, without any pensive
thought, what you do, or what shall become of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Sir, if you calculate all occasions, I have not merited this neglect
from you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Yes, and more; do you not remember what tasks you were
wont to put me to, and expenses? when I bestowed on you gowns and
petticoats, and you in exchange, gave me bracelets and shoe-ties? how
you fooled me sometimes, and set me to pin pleats in your Ruff, two
hours together, and made a waiting frippery of me? how you racked
my brain, to compose verses for you, a thing I could never abide? nay,
in my conscience, if I had not took courage, you had brought me to
spin, and beat me with your flippers.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Well Sir, I perceive you are resolved to hear no reason; but
before my sorrowful departure, know, she that you slight, is the preserver
of your life; therefore I dare be bold to call you Ingrate, and
in that I have spoke all that can be ill in man.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Pray stay, come back a little.

sp.speaker: Luc.
Aur.
sp.p:
That I should owe my life to her! which way, I wonder?
something depends on this, I must win out, well I will not forswear it,
but the toy may take me in the head, and I may see her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Has he such rare things say you?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, I believe you have not seen the like of them, they are
a couple of old Manuscripts, found in a wall, and stored up with the
foundation, it may be they are the writings of some Prophetess.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What moves you to think so Petro?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Because Sir the characters are so imperfect, for time has eaten
out the letters, and the dust makes a parenthesis betwixt every
syllable.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
A shrewd convincing argument; this fellow has a notable
reach with him, go, bid him enter, a hundred to one some fool has
them in possession, that knows not their value, it may be a man may
purchase them for little or nothing --

div1.stage: Enter Lionell like a Scholar with two books.

sp.p:
Come near friend, let me see what you have there; umh, it is as I said,
they are of the old Roman binding, what is the price of these?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
I would be loath Sir, to sell them under rate, only to merit
laughter for my rashness, therefore I thought good to bestow them
on you, and refer myself to your wisdom and free nature for my
satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
You say well, then am I bound again in conscience to deal justly
with you, will five hundred Crowns content you?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: I will demand no more Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Petro see them delivered; now I need not fear to tell you what
they are: this is a book de Republica, it is Marcus Tullius Cicero's
own handwriting, I have some other books of his penning, give me
assurance of it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And what is the other Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
This other is a book of Mathematics that was long lost in
darkness, and afterwards restored by Ptelomy.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
