I wonder Sir, unless you were times secretary, how you should
arrive to this intelligence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I know it by more than inspiration, you had them out of a
wall you say.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Well then, however you came by them, they were first brought
to Venice by Cardinal Girmannus a Patriarch, and were digged out of
the ruins of Aquileya, after it was sacked by Attila the King of the Hunnes.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: This to me is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Petro, I mean to retire, and give myself wholly to contemplation
of these studies; and because nothing shall hinder me, I mean to
lease out my Lands, and live confined; enquire me out a chapman that
will take them of me.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: If you please to let them, Sir, I will help you to a tenant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Will you, Sir? with all my heart, and I will afford him the better
bargain for your sake.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
He may pay the rent with counters, and make him believe they
are Antiquities.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is the yearly rent of them, Petro?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
They have been racked, Sir, to three thousand crowns, but the
old rent was never above fifteen hundred.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Go to, you have said enough, I will have no more than the old
rent; name your man, and the Indentures shall be drawn.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p:
Before I propose that Sir, I thought good to acquaint you
with a speciality I found among other writings, which having a seal to
it, and a name subscribed, does most properly belong to you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Let me see it; what is here, Signior Iovanno Veterano, de Monto
Nigro, he was my great Grandfather, and this is an old debt of his,
that remains yet uncancelled; you could never have pleased me better
to my cost, this ought in conscience to be discharged, and I will see it satisfied,
the first thing I do; come along.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Will you afford your Nephew, no exhibition out of your
estate, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Not a Sol, not a Gazet, I have Articles to propose before the
Senate, shall disinherit him?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Have you Sir? not justly, I hope; pray what are they?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: One of them is, he sent me Letters beyond sea, dated Stilo Novo.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: That was a great oversight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Then you remember, Petro, he took up commodities new fashioned
stuffs, when he was under age too, that he might cozen his
creditors.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And afterwards found out a new way to pay them too.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
He served them but in their kind Sir, perhaps they meant to have
cheated him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
It is all one, I will have no such practises; but the worst of all,
one time when I found him drunk, and chid him for his vice, he had
no way to excuse himself, but to say he would become a new man.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: That was heinously spoken indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
These are sufficient aggravations to anyone that shall understand
my honour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: These Gentlemen shall be witnesses to the bonds, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I hardly believe it, when you hear our message.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why? I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I am sorry to be made the unkind instrument to wrong you,
but since it is a task imposed from so great a command, I hope you will
the easier be induced to dispense with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come nearer to your aim, I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Then thus Sir, the Duke had been informed of your rarities,
and holding them an unfit treasure for a private man to possess, he
hath sent his mandamus to take them from you. See, here is his hand
for the delivery.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, o.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What ails you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I am struck with a sudden sickness, some good man help to
keep my soul in that is rushing from me, and will by no means be entreated
to continue.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Pray Sir be comforted.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Comfort; no, I despise it, he has given me daggers to my heart.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Show yourself a man Sir, and contemn the worst of fortune.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Nay, if it would stop these, it were well, but it is a punishment
will follow me after death and afflict me worse than a fury.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I much pity the Gentleman's case,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Think what it is to lose a son, when you have brought him up,
or after a seven years voyage, to see your ship sunk in the harbour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: It were a woeful spectacle indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
They are but ticklings to this, I have been all my life agathering
what I must now lose in a moment; the sacking of a city, is nothing
to be compared with it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And thatis lamentable.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It will but only give you a light to conceive of my misery.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p:
Pray Sir, be not importunate to take them this time, but try
rather, if by any means you can revoke the Decree.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: It will be somewhat dangerous, but for your sake, I will try.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Shall I hope any comfort? and upon my credit, Gentlemen, I will
appoint you all mine heirs, so soon as I am dead.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Nay, and because you shall not long gape after it, I will dye within
a month, and set you down all joint Executors.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p:
But when you are freed from the terror of his imposition, will
you not recant?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Nay, if you doubt me, walk along, and I will confirm it upon
you instantly.

sp.speaker: AEmil.
sp.l: WHy, gentle Boy, think what a happy bliss
Thou shalt enjoy, before thou knowest what it is.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: It will be a dear experiment, to waste
My prime, and flower of youth, and suffer all
Those liquid sweets to be extracted from me,
By the hot influence of consenting lust:
only to find, how well you can express
What skilful arts are hid in wickedness.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Thou dreamest, fond Boy, those sweets of youth and beauty,
Were lent, to be employed upon their like;
And when they both do meet and are extinguished,
From their mixed heat, a rich perfume shall rise,
And burn to love, a grateful sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: But I will not be so prodigal, to lavish
Such gifts away, that be irrevocable,
And yet the first that leave us.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: It will be never exacted,
How soon you have bestowed them, but how well:
What good or profit can a hidden treasure
Do more than feed the misers greedy eye?
When, if it were well bestowed, it might enrich
The owner, and the user of it; such
Is youth, and Natures bounty, that receive
A gain from the expense: but, were there none
But a mere damage, yet the pleasure of it,
And the delight, would recompense the loss.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Whatever the pleasure be, or the delight,
I am too young, not plumed for such a flight.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Too young, a poor excuse; alas, your will
Is weaker than your power: noone can be
Too young to learn good arts; and for my part,
I am not taken with a boisterous sinew,
A brawny limb, or back of Hercules;
But with a soft delicious beauty; such
As people, looking on his doubtful sex,
Might think him male or female.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cannot blame
These just Italians, to lock up their wives,
That are so free and dissolute; they labour,
Not with their country's heat, more than their own.
Will you be satisfied? I am too young.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Too young, I like you the better; there is a price
Due to the early Cherry: the first Apples
Deserve more grace; the budding rose is set by;
But stale, and fully blown, is left for vulgars
To rub their sweaty fingers on. Too young!
As well you may affirm the tender tree
Too young to graft upon, or you may say,
The rising Sun is too young to court the day.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: But there are bonds, Hymen has laid upon you,
Keep us asunder.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Those are only toys,
Shadows, mere apparitions of doubt
To affright children: do but yield unto me,
My arms shall be thy sphere to wander in,
Circled about with spells to charm these fears;
And when thou sleep'st, Cupid shall crown thy slumbers
With thousand shapes of lustful dalliance,
Then will I bathe thee in Ambrosia,
And from my lips distill such Nectar on thee,
Shall make thy flesh immortal.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How now wife, is this your exercise?
Wife did I say? stain of my blood and issue,
The great Antipathy unto my nature,
Courting your Paramour; death to my honour,
What have I seen and heard? curse of my fate!
Would I had first been deaf, or thou struck dumb,
Before this Gorgon, this damned vision
Have numbed my faculties.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: What have you seen
Or heard, more than a Dialogue I read
This morning in a book?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Would thou and that book
Were both burnt for Heretics; you geniall powers,
Why did you send this serpent to my bosom,
to pierce me through with greater cruelty,
Than Cleopatra felt from stings of Adders?
Hence from my sight, thou venom to my eyes,
Would I could look thee dead, or with a frown,
Dissect thee into Atoms, and then had them
About the world, to cast infection,
And blister all they light on.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: You are mad, and rave without a cause.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O heavens! she means
To justify her sin; canst thou redeem
Thy lost fame, and my wrongs?

sp.speaker: AEmil.
sp.l: No Sir, I will leave you,
You are too passionate.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pray Sir be satisfied, we meant no hurt.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What charms held back my hand, I did not let
Her foul blood out? then throw it into the air,
Whence it might mount up to the higher region,
And there convert into some fearful Meteor,
To threaten all her kindred. Stay, sweet child,
For thou art virtuous, yet go however,
Thou puttest me in remembrance of some ill.
Diana blush Acteon to a Stag?
What shall Lust do? Chastity made horns!
I shall be grafted with a horrid pair,
And between every branch, a written scroll
Shall speak my shame, that Foot-boys shall discern it,
And Sailors read it as they pass along:
If I bear this, I have no soul nor spleen,
I must invent some mischief; smallest cares
Are talkative, whilst great ones silent are.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: What have I done? that with a clew of lust,
Have wrought myself in such a Labyrinth,
Whence I shall never get free: there is no wrong,
Like to the breach of wedlock, those injuries
Are writ in Marble, Time shall never raze out;
The hearts of such, if they be once divided,
Will never grow one again; sooner you may
Call the spent day, or bid the stream return,
That long since slid beside you: I am lost,
Quite forfeited to shame, which till I felt,
I never foresaw, so was the less prepared.
But yet they say, a woman's wit is sudden,
And quick at an excuse; I was too foolish,
Had he confounded heaven and earth with oaths,
I might have sworn him down, or wept so truly,
That he should sooner question his own eyes,
Than my false tears; this had been worth the acting,
Or else I might have stood to the defence of it,
Been angry, and took a courage from my crimes;
But I was tame and ignorant.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Save you Lady.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: O Signior Lionell, you have undone me.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Who I! which way?

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: The boy you brought my husband.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Aye; what of him?

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: He is a witch, a thief;
That has stolen all my honours; his smooth visage
Seemed like to a Sea becalmed, or a safe harbour,
Where love might ride securely, but was found
A dangerous quick-sand, wherein are perished
My hopes and fortunes, by no art or engine
To be weighed up again.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Instruct me how.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Teach me the way then that I may relate
My own ill story, with as great a boldness
As I did first conceive, and after act it;
What wicked error lead my wandering thoughts
To gaze on his false beauty, that has proved
The fatal minute of my minds first ruin?
Shall I be brief?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: What else.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: How can I speak
Or plead with hope, that have so foul a cause?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: You torture me too much; the fear of evil
Is worse than the event.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Then, though my heart
Abhor the memory, I will tell it out;
The boy I mentioned (whatever power
Did lay on me so sad a punishment)
I did behold him with a lustful eye,
And which is the perfection of sin,
Did woe him to my will.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Well, what of that?
You are not the first offender in that kind.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: My suit no sooner ended, but came in
My jealous husband.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: That was something indeed.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Who overheard us all.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: A shrewd mischance.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Judge with what countenance he did behold me,
Or I view him, that had so great a guilt
Hang on my brow; my looks and hot desire
Both fell together: whilst he big with anger,
And swollen high with revenge, hastes from my presence
only to study how to instruct some torture,
Which I stay to expect, and here you see
The suffering object of his cruelty.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Methinks it were an easy thing for one
That were ingenious, to retort all
On his own head, and make him ask forgiveness.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: That would be seen indeed.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: I have been fortunate
In such turns in my days.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Could you do this,
I would swear you had more wit than Mercury,
Or his son Autolicus, that was able
To change black into white.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Do not despair,
I have a genius was never false to me;
If he should fail me now in these extremes;
I would not only wonder, but renounce him;
He tells me something may be done, be ruled:
And if I plot not so, to make all hit,
Then you shall take the mortgage of my wit.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: However Sir, you speakest comfortably.

div1.stage: Enter Aurelio above, duke and Leonardo over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Good morrow Gentlemen; what, you are for the feast, I
perceive.

sp.speaker: Duke.
Aur.
sp.p: My own Sir, now, I thank ill fortune, and a good wife.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
What, are you married, and your friends not preacquainted,
this will be construed amongst them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
A stolen wedding, Sir; I was glad to apprehend any occasion,
when I found her inclining: we will celebrate the solemnities hereafter,
when there shall be nothing wanting to make our Hymen happy, and
flourishing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: In good time, Sir; who is your Spouse, I pray?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Marry Sir, a creature, for whose sake I have endured many a
heat and cold, before I could vanquish her; she has proved one of Hercules
labours to me, but Time that perfects all things, made my long
toil and affection both successful; and in brief, it is Mistress Lucretia, as
very a haggard as ever was brought to fist.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Indeed, I have often heard you much complain of her coyness
and disdain; what auspicious charm has now reconciled you together?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
There is, Sir, a critical minute in every man's wooing, when
his Mistress may be won, which if he carelessly neglect to prosecute, he
may wait long enough before he gain the like opportunity.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
It seems, Sir, you have lighted upon it, we wish you much
joy in your fair choice.

sp.speaker: Aur.
Duke.
sp.p:
No Sir, that would be uncivil, we will wait some finer occasion
to gratulate your rites: good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Your servant! nay, lie you still, and dare not so much as proffer
to mutter, for if you do, I vanish; now, if you will revolt, you may.
I have laid a stain upon your honour, which you shall wash off as
well as you can.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Was this done like a Gentleman, or indeed like a true Lover,
to bring my name in question, and make me no less than your whore,
was I ever married to you? speak.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, but you may when you please.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Why were you then so impudent, to proclaim such a falsehood,
and say I was your wife, and that you had lain with me, when it was
no such matter.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Because I meant to make you so, and no man else should do it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
S'light, this is a device to over-reach a woman with; he has
madded me, and I would give a hundred crowns I could scold out
my anger.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Come, there is no injury done to you, but what lies in my
power to make whole again.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Your power to make whole? I will have no man command me
so far; what can any lawful Jury judge of my honesty, upon such
proofs as these, when they shall see a Gentleman making himself ready
so early, and saluting them out of the chamber? whether (like a false
man) thou hast stolen in by the bribery of my servant, is this no scandal?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
It was done on purpose, and I am glad my inventions thrive so,
therefore do not stand talking, but resolve.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What should I resolve?

sp.speaker: Aur.
Luc.
sp.p:
Some Politician counsel me; there is no such torment to a woman,
though she affect a thing never so earnestly, yet to be forced to it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What, are you agreed?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Well, you are a tyrant, lead on; what must be, must be, but if
there were any other way in the earth, to save my reputation, I would never
have thee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then I must do you a courtesy against your will.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Come honest cook, let me see how thy imagination has wrought
as well as thy fingers, and what curiosity thou hast shown in the preparation
of this banquet; for, gluttoning delights to be ingenious.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p:
I have provided you a feast, Sir, of twelve dishes, whereof
each of them is an Emblem of one of the twelve signs in the Zodiac.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well said, who will now deny that Cookery is a mystery?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Look you Sir, there is the List of them.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Aries, Taurus, Gemini; good:
For Aries, a dish of Lamb-stones and sweet breads;
For Taurus, a sirloin of Beef;
For Gemini, a brace of Pheasants.
For Cancer, a buttered Crab.

For Libra, a Balance, in one scale a Custard, in the other a Tart, thatis
a dish for an Alderman.
For Virgo, a green Salad.
For Scorpio, a grand one.
For Sagittarius, a Pasty of venison.
For Aquarius, a Goose.
For Pisces, two Mullets: is that all?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Read on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
And in the middle of the Table, to have an artificial Hen made
of puff-paste, with her wings displayed, sitting upon Eggs composed of
the same materials, where in each of them shall be enclosed a fat
Nightingale, well seasoned with Pepper and Ambergris: so then
will I add one invention more of my own; for, I will have all these
descend from the top of my roof, in a Throne, as you see Cupid or Mercury in a Play.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: That will be rare indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
See, the guests are come; go, and make all ready. Gentles, you
are welcome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Is the Antiquary arrived, or no; can you tell, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Not yet, but I expect him each minute --
See, your word has charmed him hither already.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Signior, you are happily encountered, and the rather, because
I have good news to tell you, the Duke has been so gracious, as to release
his demand for your Antiquities.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Has he? you have filled me all over with spirit, with which I
will mix sixteen glasses of wine, to his health, the first thing I do;
would I knew his Highness, or had a just occasion to present my
loyalty at his feet.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
For that, take no thought, it shall be my care to bring you,
and Signior Petrutio here, both before him: I have already acquainted
him with both your worths, and for aught I can gather by his speech,
he intends to do you some extraordinary honours; it may be he will
make one a Senator, because of his age; and on the other, bestow his
daughter, or niece in marriage; there is some such thing hatching,
I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Very likely, I imagined as much, that last shall be my lot; I knew
some such destiny would befall me, shall we be jovial upon this news,
and thrust all sadness out of doors?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
For our parts, Vitellius was never so voluptuous; all our discourse
shall run wit to the last.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our mirth shall be the quintessence of pleasure,
And our delight flow with that harmony;
The ambitious spheres shall to the centre shrink,
To hear our music; such ravishing accents,
As are from Poets in their fury hurled,
When their outrageous raptures fill the world.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: There spoke my genius.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Now you talk of Music, have you ever a one that can play us
and old lesson, or sing us an old song?

sp.speaker: Pet.
Ant.
sp.p: Such a one would I hear.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Walk in then, and it shall not be long before I satisfy your
desire.

div1.stage: Enter Petro and Iulia, with two Bottles.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Come, Master Petro, welcome heartily, while they are drinking
within, we will be as merry as the maids; I stole these Bottles from under
the cupboard, apurpose, against your coming.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Courteous Mistress Iulia, how shall I deserve this favour
from you?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
There is a way, Master Petro, if you could find it; but the
tenderness of your youth keeps you in ignorance; it is a great fault, I
must tell you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I shall strive to amend it, if you please to instruct me, Lady.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Alas, do not know what Maids love all this while? you must
come oftener amongst us, want of company keeps the spring of your
blood backward.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
It does so, but you shall see when we are private, I shall begin
to practise with you better.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Master Petro, this was kindly done of you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What is my Master adoing, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p:
Why they are as jovial as twenty beggars, drink their whole
cups, six glasses at a health, your Master is almost tipped already.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: So much the better, his business is the sooner despatched.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p:
Well, let not us stand idle, but verify the proverb, Like Master,
like man; and it shall go hard, Master Petro, but we will put you in
the same Cue.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Let me have fair play, put nothing in my cup, and do your
worst.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p:
Unless the cup have that virtue, to retain the print of a kiss,
or the glance of an eye to enamour you, nothing else I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: For that, I shall be more thirsty of, than of the liquor.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p:
Then let us make no more words, but about it presently; come
Master Petro, will you walk in?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I attend you.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p:
It shall go hard but I will drink him asleep, and then work some
knavery upon him.

div1.stage: Enter Duke, Leonardo, and the Antiquary drunk.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will drink with all Xerxes army now, a whole river at a draught.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Byrlady Lady Sir, that requires a large swallow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
It is all one, to our noble Dukes health, I can drink no less, not
a drop less; and you his servants will pledge me, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, if you could show us a way, when we had done,
how to build water-mills in our bellies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Do you what you will, for my part, I will begin it again and
again, till Bacchus himself shall stand amazed at me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
But should this quantity of drink come up, it were enough to
breed a deluge, and drown a whole country.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
No matter, they can never dye better, than to be drowned in
the Dukes health.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Well Sir, I will acquaint him how much he is beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will you believe me, Gentlemen, upon my credit?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes Sir, anything.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you see these breeches then?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Aye, what of them?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: These were Pompeys breeches, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
He had his denomination from them, he was called Pompey the
great, from wearing of these great breeches.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I never heard so much before.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
And this was Iulius Caesar's hat, when he was killed in the Capitoll,
and I am as great as either of them at this present.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Like enough so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And in my conceit I am as honourable.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If you are not, you deserve to be.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where is Signior Petrutio?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Nay good Father, do not trouble me now, it is enough now,
that I have promised you to go to the Duke with me; in the mean time
let me work out matters, do not dog me in the way of my preferment;
when I am a nobleman, I will do by you, as Iupiter did by the
other Deities, that is, I will let down my chair of honour, and pull
you up after me.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.p: Well, you shall rule me son.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Signior, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I have been forcing my brain to the composition of a few verses
in the behalf of your entertainment, and I never knew them flow
so dully from me before, an Exorcist would have conjured you up half
a dozen spirits in the space.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Indeed I heard you make a fearful noise, as if you had been in
travail with some strange monster.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
But I have brought them out at last, I thank Minerva; and
without the help of a midwife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Reach me a chair: I will sit down, and read them for you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You read them!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Yes, but I will put on my optics first, look you, these were Hannibals
spectacles.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why, did Hannibal wear spectacles?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Yes, after he grew dim with dust in the following the Camp, he
wore spectacles; reach me the paper.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No, an Author must recite his own works.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then I will sit and sleep.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Read on Signior.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: They were made to show how welcome you are to me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Read them out.

l.emph: As welcome as the Gentry is to the Town,
After a long and hard vacation:
As welcome as a tossed ship is to a harbour,

div1.stage:
While hee
reades, the
Antiquary
falls asleep.

l.emph: Health to the sick, or a cast suit to a Barber:
Or as a good new Play is to the times,
When they have long surfeited with base Rimes:
As welcome as the spring is to the year,
So are my friends to me, when I have good cheer.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Aye marry Sir, we are doubly beholding to you; what, is Signior
Venterano fallen asleep, and at the recitation of such verses? a most
inhumane disgrace, and not to be digested!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Has he wronged me so discourteously? I will be revenged by
Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But which way can you parallel so foul an injury?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I will go in, and make some verses against him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
That you shall not, it is not requital sufficient, I have a better
trick than so; come, bear him in, and you shall see what I will invent
for you, this was a wrong and a half.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Now, Master Lionell, as you have been fortunate in the forecasting
of this business, so pray be studious in the executing, that we
may both come off with honour.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Observe but my directions, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
The whole adventure of my credit depends upon your
care and evidence.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Let no former passage discourage you, be but as peremptory as
cause is good.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Nay, if I but once apprehend a just occasion to usurp over him,
let me alone to talk and look scurvily --
Step aside, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
My wife! some Angel guard me; the looks of Medusa were
not so ominous, I will haste from the infection of her sight, as from the
appearance of a Basilisk.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Nay Sir, you may tarry; and if virtue has not quite forsook
you, or that your ears be not altogether obdurate to good counsel,
consider what I say, and be ashamed of the injuries you have wrought
against me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
What unheard of evasion has the subtlety of woman's nature
suggested to her thoughts, to come off now?

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Well Sir, however you carry it, it is I have reason to complain,
but the mildness of my disposition, and enjoined obedience, will not
permit me, though indeed your wantonness and ill carriage, have
sufficiently
provoked me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Provoked you, I provoked you! as if any fault in a husband
should warrant the like in his wife; no, it was thy lust, and mightiness
of desire that is so strong within thee: hadst thou no company, no
masculine object to look upon, yet thy own fancy were able to create
a creature, with whom thou mightst commit, though not an actual,
yet a mental wickedness.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
What recompense can you make me, for those slanderous conceits,
when they shall be proved false to you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Hear me, thou base woman, thou that art the abstract of all
ever yet was bad, with whom mischief is so incorporate, that you are
both one piece together, and but that you go still hand in hand, the devil
were not sufficient to encounter with, for thou art indeed, able to
instruct him, do not imagine, with this frontless impudence, to stand
daring of me, I can be angry, and as quick in the execution of it, I can.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Be as angry as you please, truth and honesty will be confident,
in despite of you, those are virtues that will look Justice it self in
the face.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Aye, but where are they? not anear you, thou wouldst blast them
to behold thee; scarce I think in the world, especially such worlds as
you women are.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Umh, to see what an easy matter it is, to let a jealous peevish
husband go on, and rebuke him at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
So lewd and stubborn, mads me; speak briefly, what objection
can you allege against me; or for yourself?

sp.speaker: AEm.
Lor.
sp.p: What exploits, what concealed trulls?

sp.speaker: AEm.
Lor.
sp.p: I am more in a maze, more involved in a Labyrinth, than before.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
You were best plead innocence too, it is your safest refuge, but
I did not think a man of your age and beard, had been so lascivious to
keep a disguised caller under your nose, a base cockatrice in pages apparel,
to wait upon you, and rob me of my due benevolence, there is no
law nor equity to warrant this.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why, do I any such thing?

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Pray what else is the boy, but your own Hermaphrodite? a female
Siren in a male out-side, alas, had I intended what you suspect,
and accuse me for; I had been more wary, more
private in the carriage
I assure you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why, is that boy otherwise than he appears to be?

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
It is a thing will quickly be searched out, your secret bawdry,
and the murder of my good name will not long lie hid, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Now is my Cue to second her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Signior Lionell most welcome, I would entreat your advise here
to the clearing of a doubt.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: What is that Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It is concerning the boy you placed with me.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Aye, what of him?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Whether it were an enchantment or no, or an illusion of the
sight, or if I could persuade myself it was a dream, it were better, but
my imagination so persuaded me that I heard my wife and him interchanging
amorous discourse together; to what an extremity of passion
the frailty of man's nature might induce me to.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Not very good neither, but after the expense of so much anger
and distraction, my wife comes upon me again, and affirms that
he is no boy, but a disguised mistress of my own, and upon this swells
against me, as if she had lain all night in the leaven.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p: Have not I reason?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Pray Sir will you inform us of the verity of his sex.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Then take it upon my word, it is a woman.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p: Now Sir, what have you to answer?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I am not yet thoroughly satisfied, but if it be a woman, I must
confess my error.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
What satisfaction is that, after so great a wrong, and the taking
away of my good name, you forget my deserts, and how I brought
you a dowry of ten talents, besides I find no such superfluity of courage
in you to do this neither.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Well, were he a boy or no, it is more than I can affirm, yet
this I will swear, I entertained him for no mistress, and I hope you for no
servant, therefore good wife be pacified.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
No Sir, I will call my kindred and my friends together, then present
a joint complaint of you to the Senate, and if they right me not,
I will protest there is no justice in their Court or government.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
If she have this plea against me, I must make my peace, she will
undo me else; sweet wife, I ask thee forgiveness upon my knees, if
thou wilt have me; I rejoice more that thou art clear, than I was angry
for the supposed offence, be but patient, and the liberty thou enjoyedest
before shall be thought thralldom hereafter: sweet Sir, will you
mediate?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
Come sweet Lady, upon my request you shall be made friends,
it was but a mistake, conceive it so, and he shall study to redeem it.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Well Sir, upon this Gentleman's entreaty, you have your pardon,
you know the propensity of my disposition, and that makes you
so bold with me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Pray master Lionell will you acquaint my wife with the purpose
of this concealment, for I am utterly ignorant, and she has not the patience
to hear me.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p:
It requires more privacy than so, neither is it yet ripe for projection,
but because the community of Counsel is the only pledge of
friendship, walk in and I will acquaint you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Honest sweet wife I thank thee with all my heart.

div1.stage:
Enter Duke, Leonardo, and Petrutio bringing in the Antiquary
in a fools coat.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: So set him down softly, then let us slip aside and overhear him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Where am I? what metamorphosis am I crept into? a fools
coat! what is the Emblem of this trow? who has thus transformed me
I wonder? I was awake, am I not asleep still; why Petro you rogue,
sure I have drunk of Circes cup, and that has turned me to this shape
of a fool, if I had drunk a little longer, I had been changed into an
ass, why Petro I say, I will not rest calling till thou comest --

Hoyday, what more transmigrations of forms, I think Pythagoras has
been amongst us, how came you thus accoutred Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Why Sir, the wenches made me drunk, and dressed me as
you see.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
A merry world the while, my boy and I make one hermaphrodite,
and now next Midsummer ale, I may serve for a fool, and he for a
maid Marrian.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Who is this Signior Veterano?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
The same Sir, I was not so when you left me, do you know
who has thus abused me?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You promised to do me a courtesy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Anything lies in my power.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then pray will you bring me immediately to the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Not as you are I hope.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Yes as I am, he shall see how I am wronged amongst them, I
know he loves me, and will right me; pray Sir, forbear persuasion
to the contrary, and lead on.

div1.stage: Enter Lorenzo, Moccinigo, AEmilia, and Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Now Signior Moccinigo, what haste requires your presence?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Marry Sir this, you brought me once into a paradise of pleasure,
and expectation of much comfort, my request therefore is, that
you would no longer defer, what then you so liberally promised.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Why sir, in joining that beauteous Lady your daughter, and
myself in the firm bonds of matrimony, for I am somewhat impatient
of delay in this kind, and indeed the height of my blood requires it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Are you so hot, I shall give you a card to cool you presently.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
It is an honest and a virtuous demand, and on all sides an action
of great consequence, and for my part, there is not a thing in the
world, I could wish sooner accomplished.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: Thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
There is another branch of policy besides the complying of you
two together, which springs from the fruitfulness of my brain, that I
as much labour to bring to perfection as the other.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: What is that Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
A devise upon the same occasion, but with a different respect,
it is to be imposed upon Petrutio, I hate to differ so much from the nature
of an Italian, as not to be revengeful, and the occasion at this time
was, he scorned the love of her, that you now so studiously affect; but
I will fit him in his kind.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Did he so? he deserves to have both his eyes struck as blind as
Cupids his master, that should have taught him better manners; but
how will you do it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: There is one Lionell an ingenious witty Gentleman.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p: Aye that he is, as ever breathed, husband upon my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Well, he is so, and we two have cast to requite it upon him,
the plot as he informs me is already in agitation, and afterwards sans
delay, I will bestow her upon you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you may be deceived.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: Still you engage me more and more your debtor.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
If I can bring both these to success, as they are happily intended,
I may sit down, and with the Poet cry Iamq; opus exegi.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Would I could say so too, I wish as much, but it is you must
confirm it, fair mistress, one bare word of your consent, and it is
done, the sweetness of your looks encourage me, that you will join
pity with your beauty, there shall be nothing wanting to me to demerit
it, and then I hope, although I am base,
sp.l: Base in respect of you, divine and pure;
Dutiful service may your love procure.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
How now Signior, what, love and poetry have they two found
you out? nay then you must conquer; consider this, daughter, show
thy obedience to Phoebus and God Cupid, make an humble proffer of
thyself, it will be the more acceptable, and advance thy deserts.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p: Do chicken, speak the word, and make him happy in a minute.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Well said wife, solicit in his behalf, it is well done, I am loath to
importune her too much for fear of a repulse.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Marry come up Sir, you are still usurping in my company, is
this according to the articles proposed between us, that I should bear
rule, and you obey with silence; I had thought to have endeavoured
for persuasion, but because you exhort me to it, I will desist from what
I intended, I will do nothing but of my own accord, I.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Mum wife, I have done; thus we that are married must be subject
to.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: You give an ill example, mistress Aemilia, you give an example

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
What old fellow is this, that talks so; do you know him
daughter?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: Have you so soon forgot me, Lady?

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Where has he had his breeding I wonder? he is the off-spring
of some peasant sure, can he show any Pedigree?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Let her alone, there is no dealing with her, come daughter, let
me hear you answer to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Truly Sir, I have endeavoured all means possible, and in a
manner enforced myself to love him.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well said girl.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But could never effect it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I have examined whatever might commend a Gentleman, both
his exterior and inward abilities, yet amongst all, that may speak
him worthy, I could never discern one good part or quality, to invite
affection.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
This is it I feared, now should I break out into rage, but my
wife and a foolish nature with-hold my passion.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
I am undone, unspirited, my hopes vain, and my labours
nullities.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Where be your large vaunts now Signior, what strange tricks
and devises you had to win a woman!

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Such assurance I conceived of myself, but when they affect
wilful stubbornness, lock up their ears, and will hearken to no manner
of persuasion, what shall a man do?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
You hear what taxes are laid upon your daughter, these are
stains to your other virtues.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Pray Sir, hear my defence, what sympathy can there be between
our two ages, or agreement in our conditions? but you will object
he has means, it is confessed: but what assurance has he to keep it? will
it continue longer than the law permits him possession? which will
come like a torrent, and sweep away all; he has made a forfeiture of
his whole estate.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
What are you become a Statists daughter, or a Prophetess?
whence have you this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: I hope she will not betray me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If murder can exact it, it is absolutely lost.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How, murder!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Yes, he conspired the other day with a Bravo, a cut-throat, to
take away the life of a noble innocent Gentleman, which is since discovered
by miracle; the same that came with music to my window.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
All is out, I am ruined in her confession; that man that trusts woman
with a privacy, and hopes for silence, he may as well expect it at
the fall of a bridge; a secret with them is like a viper, it will make way,
though it eat through the bowels of them.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Take heed, how you traduce a person of his rank and eminency,
a scar in a mean man becomes a wound in a greater.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There he is, question him; and if he deny it, get him examined.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why Signior, is this true?

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p: His silence bewrays him, it is so.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
It is so, that all women thirst man's overthrow; that is a principle
as demonstrative as truth; it is the only end they were made for:
and when they have once insinuated themselves into our counsels, and
gained the power of our life, the fire is more merciful, it burns within
them till it get forth.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I commend her for the discovery, it was not fit her weak thoughts
should be clogged with so foul a matter; it had been to her like forced
meat to a surfeited stomach, that would have bred nothing but crudities
in her conscience.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
O my cursed fate! shame and punishment attend me, they
are the fruits of lust; Sir, all that I did, was for her ease and liberty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Nay Sir, he was so impudent to be an accessory, who knows
but he might as privately have plotted to have sent me after him, for
how should I have been secure of my life, when he made no scruple to
kill another upon so small an inducement?

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Thou sayst right, daughter, thou shalt utterly disclaim him;
the cast of his eye shows he was ever a knave.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p: How the scabs descant upon me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What was the motive to this foul attempt?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Why Sir, because he was an affectionate love of mine, and for
no other vile reason in the earth.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
O mandrake, was that all? he thought belike, he should not
have enough: thou covetous engrosser of venery, why, one wife is able
to content two husbands.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Sir, I am at your mercy, bid them not insult upon me; I beseech
you let me go as I came.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Stay there, I know not how I shall censure your escape, so I may
be thought a party in the business.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Besides I hear since that the mercenary varlet that did it, though
he be otherwise most desperate, and hardened in such exploits, yet
since out of the apprehension of so unjust an act, and moved in conscience
for so foul a guilt, is grown distracted, raves out of measure, confesses
the deed, accuses himself and the procurer, curses both; and will by
no means be quieted.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Where is that fellow?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Sir, if you please to accompany me, I will bring you to him,
where your own eye and ear shall witness the certainty, and then I
hope, you will repent that ever you fought to tie me to such a monster
as this, who preferred the heat of his desires before all laws of nature or
humanity.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Yes that I will, and gratulate the subtlety of thy will, and goodness
of fate, that protected thee from him.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Away with him husband, and be sure to beg his lands betimes,
before your Court vultures sent his carcase.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p:
Well said wife, I should never have thought on this now, if
thou hadst not put me in mind of it; women I see have the only masculine
policy, and are the best solicitors and politicians of a state, but
I will first go see him my daughter tells me of, that when I am truly informed
of all, I can the better proceed in my accusation against them,
come along Sir.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Well, if you are so violent, I am as resolute; it is but a hanging
matter, and do your worst.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: What news Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Sir, Mistress Lucretia commends her to you, and desires, as ever
her persuasion wrought upon you; or as you affect her good, and
would add credit and belief to what she has reported, that you
would now strain your utmost, to the expression of what she and you
consulted of.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I apprehend her, where is she?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Hard by Sir, her father and the old fornicator Moccinigo, and
I think her mother, are all coming to be spectators of your strange
behaviour.

div1.stage:
Exit.
Enter Lorenzo, Moccinigo, AEmilia, Lucretia and Boy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Is this the place?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes Sir, where is your Master, Boy? how does he?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
O sweet Mistress, quite distempered, his brains turns round like
the needle of a Dial, six men's strength is not able to hold him, he
was bound with I know not how many cords, this morning, and
broke them all -- See where he enters.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why, if I killed him, what is that to thee?
Was I not hired unto it? it was not I,
But the base gold that slew Sir Polydore:
Then damn the money.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: He begins to peach.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: Will he do us no mischief, think you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l:
O no, he is the best for that in his fits, that ever you knew, he
hurts nobody.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: But I am vilely afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
If you are a vile person, or have done any great wickedness,
you were best look to yourself, for those he knows by instinct; and
assaults them with as much violence as may be.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
Then am I perished; good Sir, I had rather answer the Law,
than be terrified with his looks.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Nay you shall tarry, and take part with us, by your favour.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p: How his eyes sparkle!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Look where the ghost appears, his wounds fresh bleeding,
He frowns, and threatens me, could the substance
Do nothing, and will shadow's revenge?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It is strange,
This was a fearful murder.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Do not stare so,
I can look big too, all I did unto thee,
It was by another's instigation:
There be some that are as deep in as myself,
Go and fright them too.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Beshrew him for his counsel.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What a just judgment is here? it is an old saying,
Murder will out; and before it shall lie hid,
The authors will accuse themselves.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Now he vanishes;
Dost thou steal from me, fearful spirit? see
The print of his footsteps.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: That ever my lust should be the parent to so foul a sin!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He told me, that his horrid tragedy
Was acted over every night in hell,
Where said Erynnis with her venomed face,
Black with curls of snakes, sits a spectatrix,
That list their speckled heads above their shoulders,
And thrusting forth their stings, hiss at their entrance;
And that serves for an applause.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: How can you have the heart to look upon him? pray let me go,
I feel a looseness in my belly.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay you shall hear all out first.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: I confess it,
What would you have more of me?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Then fierce Enyo holds a torch, Megora
Another; I will down and play my part amongst them,
For I can do it to the life.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Rather to the death.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will trace the infernal Theatre, and view
Those squalid Actors, and the tragic pomp
Of hell and night.

sp.speaker: Moccio.
sp.p:
How ghastly his words sound! pray keep him off from
me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: The guilt of conscience makes you fearful, Signior.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: When I come there, I will chain up Cerberus,
Nay I will muzzle him; I will pull down AEacus,
And Minos by the beard; then with my foot
I will tumble Rhadamanthus from his chair:
And for the Furies, I will not suffer them,
I will be myself a Fury.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: To vex me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Next will I post unto the destinies,
Shiver their wheel and distaff against the wall,
And spoil their housewifery; I will take their spindle,
Where hang the threads of human life, like beams
Drawn from the Sun, and mix them all together,
Kings with the beggars.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Good Sir, he comes towards me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That I could see that old fox Moccinigo,
The villain that did tempt me to this deed.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.p:
He names me too, pray Sir stand between us, Ladies do you
speak to him, I have not the faith.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: What would you do with him, if you had him?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I would serve him worse than Hercules did Licas,
When he presented him the poisoned shirt,
Which when he had put on, and felt the smart,
He snatched him by the heels into the air,
Swung him some once or twice about his head,
Then shot him like a stone out of an engine,
Three furlongs length into the Euboick sea.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l:
What a huge progress is that, for an old Lover to be
carried?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What is he that seeks to hide himself? come forth thou mortal,
Thou art a traitor or a murderer:
O, is it you?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l:
What will become of me? pray help me, I shall be torn in
pieces else.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You and I must walk together, come into the middle yet further.

div1.stage: Enter Aurelio as an Officer, and two Servants.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Where be these fellows here that murder men? Sergeants apprehend
them, and convey them straight before the Duke.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We are the Dukes officers.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
The Dukes officers must be obeyed, take heed of displeasing
them, how majestically they look.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
You see wife, the charms of authority, if a man be never so
wild, it tames him presently.

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.p: Aye husband, I know what will tame a man besides authority.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Come gentles, since you are altogether, I must entreat your
company along with us, to witness what you know in this behalf.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Sir, you have prevented us, for we intended to have brought
him ourselves before his highness.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Then I hope your resolution will make it the easier to you;
what Sir, will you go willingly?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Without all contradiction, lead on.

div1.stage:
Flourish.
Enter Lionell as the Duke; Duke, Petrutio, Gasparo,
Angelia as a woman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come Signior,
This is the morning must shine bright upon you,
Wherein preferment that has slept obscure,
And all this while lingered behind your wishes,
Shall overtake you in her greatest glories;
Ambition shall be weak, to think the honours
Shall crown your worth.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Father, you hear all this?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I do with joy, son, and am ravished at it.
Therefore I have resigned my estate unto thee,
(only reserving some few crowns to live on)
Because I would have thee to maintain thy part.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You did as you ought.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: It is enough for me,
To be the parent of so blessed an issue.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay, if you are so apprehensive, I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Is this the Gentleman you so commended?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is the same, my liege, whose royal virtues
Fitting a Princes Court, are the large field
For Fame to triumph in.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: So you informed me, his face and carriage do import no less.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Report abroad speaks him as liberally;
And in my thoughts, fortune deserves but ill,
That she detained thus long her favours from him.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: That will I make amends for.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Happy hour,
And happy me to see it; now I perceive
He has more wit than myself.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What must I do?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What must you do? go strait and kneel before him,
And thank his highness for his love.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I cannot speak,
I am so overcome with sudden gladness,
Yet I will endeavour it; most mighty Sovereign,
Thus low I bow, in humble reverence,
To kiss the basis of your regal Throne.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Rise up.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Your Graces servant.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: We admit you,
Our nearest favourite in place and counsel.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Go to, you are made forever.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I will find some office
To gratulate thy pains.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: What was the cause
That you presented him no sooner to us,
We might have bred him up in our affairs,
And he have learnt the fashions of our Court,
Which might have rendered him more active.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Doubt not,
His ingenuity will soon instruct him.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Then to confirm him deeper in our friendship,
We here assign our sister for his wife.
What, is he bashful?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Speaks your Grace in earnest?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: What else? I will have it so.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why do you not step and take her?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Is it not a kind of treason?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not, if he bid you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Divinest Lady are you so content?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What my Brother commands, I must obey.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Join hands together, be wise, and use
Your dignities with a due reverence;
Tiberius Caesar joyed not in the birth
Of great Seianus fortunes with that zeal,
As I shall to have raised you, though I hope, a different fate attends you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Go to the Church,
Perform your rights there, and return again
As fast as you can.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I could even expire with contemplation of his happiness.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: What old man is that?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: This is my Father, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Your own Father?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: So please your Grace.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Give him a pair
Of velvet breeches, from our Grandsires wardrobe

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Thrice noble Duke, come forth let us to the Church.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: How now, what new-come Pageant have we here?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
This is the famous Antiquary I told your grace of, a man
worthy your grace; the Ianus of our age, and measurer of times past,
a man worthy your bounteous favour and kind service, that will as
soon forget himself in the remembrance of your highness, or any subject
you have.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: How comes he so accoutred?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
No miracle at all; Sir, for, as you have many fools in the habit
of a wise man, so have you sometimes a wise man in the habit of
a fool.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Sir, I have been grossly abused, as no story, record or chronicle
can parallel the like, and I come here for redress; I hear your highness
loves me, and indeed you are partly interest in the cause, for I having
took somewhat a large potion for your graces health, fell asleep, when
in the interim they apparelled me as you see, made a fool, or an Asinigo
of me? and for my boy here, they cogged him out of his proper
shape, into the habit of an Amazon, to wait upon me.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: But who did this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay Sir, that I cannot tell, but I desire it may be found out.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Well Signior, if you knew all, you have no cause to be angry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Why, that same coat you wear, did formerly belong unto
Pantolabus the Roman Jester, and Buffoon to Augustus Caesar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If I thought so, I would never put it off while I breathed.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Stand by, we will enquire further anon.
sp.stage:
Enter Aurelio, Lorenzo, Moccinigo, Bravo,
AEmilia, Lucretia, Officers.
sp.l: Now, who are you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Your highness Officers,
We have brought two murderers here to be censured,
Who by their own confession are found guilty,
And need no further trial.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Which be the parties?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: These if please you.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Well, what do you answer?
What can you plead to stop the course of Justice?

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: For my part, though I had no conscience to act it,
I have not the heart to deny it, and therefore expect
Your sentence: for mercy, I hope none, nor favour.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: What says the accuser?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Please your princely wisdom,
He slew a man was destined for my husband;
Yet since another's death cannot recall him,
Were the Law satisfied, and he adjudged
To have his goods confiscate, for my own part,
I could rest well content.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: With all my heart,
I yield possession to whomsoever
She shall choose for a husband; reach a paper
Or blank, I will seal to it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: See, is a writing.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: And there is my hand to it,
I care not what the conditions be.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: It is well, whom will you choose in place of the other?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then Sir, to keep his memory alive,
I will seek no further than this officer.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How, choose a common Sergeant for her husband!

sp.speaker: AEm.
sp.l: A base commendatore, I will never endure it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l:
No Lady, a Gentleman I assure you, and supposed the slain
Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: A plot, a plot upon me, I will revoke it all.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Nay, that you cannot, now you have confirmed it.

sp.speaker: Moc.
sp.l: Am I then cheated? I will go home and dye,
To avoid shame, not live in infamy.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: What says the villain Bravo for himself?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The Bravo, Sir, is honest, and his father.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: My father! bless me, how comes this about?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That virtuous Maid, whom I must always honour,
Acquainted me with that old Lecher's drift:
I, to prevent the ruin of my son,
Concealed from all, proffered my service to him
In this disguise.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: It was a wise and pious deed.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Room for the Dukes kindred.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: What, you are married, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am, Royal Brother.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Then for your better learning in our service,
Take these instructions; never hereafter
Contemn a man that has more wit than yourself,
Or foolishly conceive no Ladies merit,
Or beauty worthy your affection.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Truth, my most honoured Brother, you are gulled,
So is my reverent uncle the Antiquary,
So are you all; for he that you conceived
The Duke, is your friend and Lionell,
Look you else.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It is so.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: It is too apparent true.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: What, all drunk? speak Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou art my Nephew,
And thou hast wit, it is fit thou shouldst have land too.
Tell me no more how thou hast cheated me,
I do perceive it, and forgive thee for it,
Thou shalt have all I have, and I will be wiser.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, Brother Petrutio,
This is your comfort, that is my Sister,
Whom formerly you did abuse in love,
And you may be glad your lot is no worse.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am contented, I will give a good wit
Leave to abuse me at any time.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: When he cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: This it is,
To be so politic and ambitious, Son.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay father, do not you aggravate it too:

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well Signior,
You must pardon me, if I bid joy to you,
My daughter was not good enough for you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You are tyrannous.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Save you Gallants.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: You are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I come in quest of our noble Duke,
Who from his Court has stolen out privately,
And it is reported he is here.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: No indeed, Sir,
He is not here; 'slight we shall be questioned
For counterfeiting his person.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be not dismayed,
I am the Duke.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The very same, Sir,
That for my recreation, have descended
(And no impeach, I hope, to royalty)
To sit spectator of your mirth: and thus much
You shall gain by my presence; what is past,
I will see it ratified as firm, as if
Myself and Senate had concluded it.
And when a Prince allows his Subjects sport,
He that pines at it, let him perish for it.
